There are 14 dice representing four woods, eight irons, a wedge and a putter. These have various ranges (in yards)appropriate for the club printed on the faces. Another die called the "directional die" has either "hook" or "slice" and a yardage on each side.

Players hit their ball (represented by a colored tee) by announcing the direction they're hitting - one of the eight cardinal points - and rolling the directional die and the die for the club they're using. The new ball positioned using the die values and the grid. There are various rules restricting club use depending on the type of landscape you're hiting from. Once you're on the green there's no direction to worry about, just range and the odds on putter die.
The manufacturing quality of the game is very good, almost extravagant. The box is hefty, there's a nice cork-lined plastic holder for the dice, a pad of score cards, and large cards printed with golf terms, club ranges, and even golf etiquette ("Replace divots.").
publishers: Ariel Productions Ltd, Rigely Banada Corp

name: Mini Double Dice
description:
A Yahtzee like game where there are 5 hollow, transparent, six-sided dice. Within each is another smaller die. You get three rolls and get to keep any number of dice on each roll, just like Yahtzee. You then score based on 13 categories. Categories are Ones, Twos, Threes, Fours, Fives, Sixes, Odds, Evens, Lo In/Hi Out, Hi In/Lo Out, Lucky 7-11, One Away, Double Dice.

An example of scoring is Lo In/Hi Out: After the third roll, total all the Double Dice (both inner and outer) that have a lower number on the inner die and a higher number on the outer die. If all 5 Double Dice are Lo In/Hi Out, total all dice and DOUBLE the score!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck, Re-rolling and Locking, Set Collection

name: What's Wild?!
description:
What's Wild?! is a rummy-based card game for 2-7 players Ages 7 and up. Instead of cards featuring suits, the game's cards are made up of four different animal skins—alligator, cheetah, peacock, and zebra. And to further the "Wild" theme of the game, when a player's hand allows him or her to end a round of play, he or she must declare, "I'm going wild!"

A complete game of What's Wild?! includes 10 rounds. Each player receives three cards to begin the first round, and by the final round, each player is holding 12 cards in his or her hand. Players collect appropriately-named "herds" and "caravans"—called "books" and "runs" in traditional rummy games— throughout each round, until they are able to "Go Wild," or end the round.

Four cards - called "Chameleon Cards" change the Wild Card when played throughout the game. The four Chameleon Cards give the game a sort of "Old Maid" feel, in that if the card is in a player's hand when another player "Goes Wild," the player holding the Chameleon Card is awarded the maximum amount of points. In a game in which the low score wins, players must carefully weigh their options for playing Chameleon Cards when holding one. Playing the card too early may allow the Wild Card to be changed in later turns, but holding on to it too long may lead to an stampede of points. The Chameleon Card makes each round of every game of What's Wild?! new, exciting, and completely unpredictable.

Home Page: http://www.whatswildcardgame.com/

name: Rappakalja Matkapeli
description:
Rappakalja Matkapeli is a travel version of Rappakalja. Main idea is to guess correct answer to given question. If player doesn't know the right answer he/she may write anything. After everybody has given their answer papers to "hämy" player and he/she has accepted them all answers are read and voting begins. Player who got most votes gets two points and second one point. So "correct" answer is not always. Usually most ridiculous or stupid answer gets all the points.

Question genres
-What happened in that date
-What does this saying mean (sayings in various languages)
-What is this medical phobia/condition
-Who is this character or where this character appeared

Travel version holds less cards and art word have been changed, also a game is little shorter!
categories: Bluffing, Humor, Party Game, Trivia, Word Game

name: Word Snag
description:
From the rules:
The youngest player starts the game then play moves to the left. On your turn take the top category card and turn it over so that all players can see it. Then the player whose turn it is rolls all 7 letter cubes. Immediately all players shout out words that relate to the category that begin with one of the letters face up on the cubes. As a player shouts out a word, that player snags the cube with that letter on it. Opponents must object immediately if they think the word just shouted does not relate to the category.

When all of the letter cubes have been snagged, or players have gone 10 seconds or more without coming up with a word, the round is over. Players score one point for each letter cube they snagged during the round. The first player to snag 20 points wins.

The rules include some variants.

Contents: 7 dice, dice cup, 30 category cards, score pad, rules.

name: Star Trek: Attack Wing – Denorios Expansion Pack
description:
The Denorios is a Bajoran Solar Sailor. These ships are powered by solar sails and are capable of traveling at faster-than-light speeds using tachyon eddies. The Denorios was piloted by Akorem Laan, a famous Bajoran poet. After his ship was damaged by an ion storm, Akorem entered the Bajoran Wormhole and returned 200 years later.
Star Trek: Attack Wing – Bajoran Lightship Expansion Pack is part of the Wave 21 expansion packs from WizKids Games, and this expansion comes with one new ship and a new set of cards for Star Trek: Attack Wing.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order

name: Sefirot
description:
Sefirot is an ancient game from the lost lands of Dioscoria. Played in numerous variations on different boards with Tarot cards, higher powers will decide upon the players’ destiny, their triumph or their downfall.

In its solitaire version a world spanning tree of life becomes the stage for the player’s challenges of the fates themselves, trying to overcome the universe’s perilous duality of growth and decay.

The game can also be played together, in numerous modes for two people: they might battle for the stars themselves or embark on a tender dance that will reveal their joined faith.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Frogger: The Board Game
description:
Frogger - The Board Game is the officially licensed by Konami fun-filled reimagining of the classic video game for the whole family. Race your frog safely across the river to get to the tasty flies before your opponents. Watch out for vehicles and obstacles that can stop you in your tracks, and be sure to avoid the other hungry predators...they're just waiting to slip you up!

Frogger the Board Game brings you back to 1981, the year Frogger was introduced in arcades everywhere. Just like the original video game, move your frog across the roads and water. Dodge cars and crocs while trying to prevent other players from achieving the same goal. Catch the most flies to win the most points! The game is played over four rounds (two water and two road) to make two complete trips across the board. After the fourth round, the player who has the most points, wins
mechanics: Area Movement, Modular Board, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Race, Slide/Push, Tile Placement, Variable Set-up, Victory Points as a Resource

name: Sacrifice 666
description:
In Sacrifice 666 you play as a clandestine cult and you’re about to summon your Dark Lord.
However, you can’t really seem to agress on who exactly it is you worship. To make matters even worse, you only have one Necronomicon….so you’re going to have to share.

The goal of the game is to sacrifice enough “people” to summon your Dark Lord to the mortal realm before those other misguided fools do.

Sacrifice is an easy to play card game. The rules are light but the humor is heavy !

name: Diversion
description:
A draughts/checkers variant in which the board squares are embossed into diamond shaped tiles, which are fitted together to form the board.

During their turn, each player may, as an alternative to moving a piece, move a tile from one place to another or even remove a tile altogether.

Should a player divide the board into two, the opponent chooses which portion remains in play.

First player to capture or immobilize the opposing pieces wins.

name: Espionaje: Cartas
description:
Espionage cards it's a dynamic and very fun game. Using your brain you have to discover the three variables of the confidential file, you have a lot of tools to your disposition. Use your private agenda...and you'll be the winner

The game is simple:
Every player recibes a deck of 15 black cards called "personal agenda"

Then you take the deck called "Confidential file" with 15 yellow cards and split it in 3 parts : 5 cards of locations (London, Athens, Paris, Tokyo and Panama), 5 cards of Spies (Orange Spy, Blue spy, Red spy, Green spy and White Spy) and 5 cards of devices (Jetpack, Airplane, Lethal Gas,Satellite and Helicopter). Shuffle every deck and take , without looking, 1 card per deck and face it down in the middle of the table. then merge the remaining cards into one deck, shuffle and deal evenly among the players.

Now its time to play!:
The objetive of the game is to discover the face down cards using logic and deduction.
First of all you know that the "confidential file" cards can't be in the center of the table so you discard those card from the "personal agenda" deck in your hand.

Now a player begins its turn by asking other players about some of their cards. For example: I ask to the player on my left for "the BLUE SPY in LONDON", or "In AIRPLANE to PANAMA". Every question must involve 2 elements of the 3 different variables (cities, spies and devices) it may include 2 of the same element, for example 2 agents, 2 cities or 2 devices.
Once the question was askes, the other player checks his/her cards of "confidential archive" and if he/she has 1 or two of those cards, he must show 1 to the player who asked. By knowing the card, you can discard what he/she shown from the personal agenda. otherwise he says "I'll pass" and another player must be asked.

The game continues like this until someone thinks that they know the cards facing down and makes and acussation! if he guesses right he wins if not the player to the left makes and acussation and so until someone wins!
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Spies/Secret Agents

name: The Battle of Lizard
description:
In The Battle of Lizard, a.k.a. 蜥蓋, players each control a group of lizards on an island competing for survival — long-term survival, that is, because when breeding time arrives, these male lizards (Uta stansburiana) will fight one another for land and the right to reproduction. To succeed, you need to block others to keep them from reproducing!

To set up the game, shuffle the cards, then deal everyone a hand of six cards, placing the other cards aside as a draw deck. Players then take turns playing a card from their hand onto the table in the breeding competition area, then refilling their hand. Cards may be rotated, but not flipped over, and a player may choose to cover other cards or place their card next to others.

As soon as someone creates a chain of five identical lizards either orthogonally or diagonally, the game ends and the player who owns this color of lizard wins. If players run out of cards, they take turns moving uncovered cards to connect or cover other cards until someone wins.

name: Auf die Weide, fertig, los!
description:
Game description from the publisher:

When the sun rises, the animals in the stables start pawing impatiently with their hooves. They are hungry and want to go out into the meadow! But farmer Tim is sick and in bed and cannot look after his animals.

In To the Meadow, Ready, Steady, Go!, the players help farmer Tim by taking the animals out to the meadow for him. The player who finds two cards with the same number of buckets among the flowers cards may gather the feed for the animals and build a path to the meadow. Whoever has good memory skills and some luck with the die will be the first to lead his animal to the meadow!

name: "In Pursuit of Par" Par 72 Edition
description: In Pursuit of Par is designed to simulate the actual game of golf as closely as practical. As in actual golf, the object is to shoot a low score, hopefully Par 72 or below. Unlike actual golf, however, all players have equal ability "swinging the clubs" and only selection of clubs, choice of direction, and luck make the difference in scores.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Das Schloss
description:
From the gamefest.com website game description: "Four daring adventurers enter the old castle...To meet the ghosts of not so daring long time gone adventurers. And to find some secret treasures and magic scrolls. Will they escape? An always new adventure game with beautiful wooden game pieces."

The game components consist of the following: cardboard box storage container; 4-player pawns; 2-DICE; 4-player cards; 20-Magic cards; 48-floor tiles; 107-playing tiles; 24-hearts; 1-Castle owner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Role Playing, Tile Placement

name: Ach, du Mauseschreck!
description:
Players roll a die to determine how many spaces to move an elephant or the mouse. If a lone elephant encounters the mouse, it is sent back to the starting square. Be the first to reach the elephant temple with two elephants.

Contents: game board, mouse pawn, 12 elephants (in 4 colors), 1 die

name: Robots vs. Dinosaurs
description:
Robots vs. Dinosaurs is the third game in the Army vs. Aliens series, with each game being playable on its own while also allowing for any faction in one game to be played against any faction in another or for multiple sets to be combined for team games or "last man standing" challenge matches.

In Robots vs. Dinosaurs, each player takes one of the factions and rolls all nine dice. Taking turns, players then either attack the opponent or use a special power. Dice that are used are placed into the dice cup. If a player cannot attack or use a power, he instead "rallies", rolling the dice cup and simultaneously rerolling all of his dice still in play.

The two forces have different special powers, and players want to move dice into their scoring zone to win. If five rounds pass without either player scoring, then the game ends and the player who has the most dice in his scoring zone wins.

name: Monopoly: House Divided
description:
A Race for the White House
It’s a Monopoly game in which players dream, campaign, and vote their way to the White House! Choose one of the Candidate tokens: a donkey, elephant, eagle, flag, peace sign, or teacup; get assigned to the red or blue party and get ready for political wheeling and dealing.

Buy States and Set Up Headquarters
Players move around the board buying as many states as they can. Own a complete color set of states and establish Campaign Headquarters to bring in more votes and more rent.

Cards Have Leverage
Flex political muscle with Executive Power cards and get perks such as getting out of Jail free, or cancelling an action played against you. I Voted cards let Players Vote on who profits — and who has to pay.

Win the Presidency
When the last state is claimed, count up the votes. The candidate with the most votes wins. Hail to the Chief!

—description from the publisher

name: Palavan
description:
A paradise island landscape is regrettably separated into different pieces. The aim is to connect the islands again!

At the basic level, the South Seas puzzle has multiple solutions and many spellbinding panoramic views of the island. A player can choose to set the goal higher in challenging game variants in search of the perfect island.

In addition to a mind-teasing game of solitaire, two players can take turns place their tiles in Palavan, with each trying to lay out all their personal tiles while making life difficult for the opponent. Life can sometimes get mean, even in an island paradise...

—description from the publisher

name: Slings and Stones
description:
Slings and Stones is a strategy boardgame which uses a standard checkerboard with chess and checkers pieces. It can easily be learned and played in a few short minutes, but mastery of the game will take much longer. Each and every move can have huge ramifications, and players will find it extremely difficult to plan more than a couple of rounds in advance.

I stumbled upon this game while skimming through some old journals I found in my grandfather�s attic. The rules were gleaned from Kardon's writings on the Muighar tribes, and I've tried my best to keep them authentic. However, as Kardon's description of the rules are not very clear, this version may vary slightly from that of antiquity.

As most of you probably don't have access to authentic Muighar Slings and Stones pieces or boards, I've taken the liberty of finding some substitutions. This game can played using a chess board, with 4 pawns and 12 checkers. Pawns represent the slings, and checkers represent the stones.

http://www.darkshadowgames.com/Epic_Registration/register.ht...
(Click "Download SLINGS.ZIP" for rules and bits)

Online Play


Super Duper Games

name: Tier-Express
description: The zoo animals are jostling to get inside the holiday express. But not all the animals will fit! Already the first ones tumble off the wagon! Who with a bit of skill will get their animals inside the train? A pushing game for 2 to 4 skillful players.

name: Гонка жуков
description:
Bug racers have come to compete from all over the world, and the first one to cross the finish line will become globally famous. Moreover, the winner will gain interplanetary fame as for the first time in the Grand Bug Races, robobugs from the space station will participate in the next stage of the competition.

Bug Race is an easy to master but still captivates as a dynamic board game race for 2-4 players from 8 years old. Each player leads his own bug to victory moving its legs one after another. Of course, legs shouldn’t be torn off the body or tangle with each other. When a bug passes all 9 levels of the playing field and crosses the finish line first, its owner wins the game.

Each bug consists of 7 elements, body and 6 legs, and runs at its own track, divided into sections. There are special notches for the bug’s legs, gashed on the each side of the track. Body, that covers three sections, is placed at the track between the legs. “Losing” legs is permitted: each leg should touch the body at least diagonally all the time. So the bug can not stretch for more than 5 sections.

When the game begins, players place their bugs at the start positions – the three first sections of the track. Tracks cross at the middle of the table and connected by the central element with the race aim on it. They are not bonded hard so players don’t pull others’ tracks while moving their own bugs. If needed, in case of lack of free space on the table for example, playing is possible without a center element. And of cause you don’t need extra tracks if there are less than 4 players.

Moving bugs is performed by using special cards. Each of them allows to move 2 or 3 legs, a front left and a middle right, for example. In the beginning of each round players draw two of such cards from the stack. One of them stays at the hand and another one goes to the next player. Then both cards in the hand should be played in any order. Player moves all the stated legs forward if there is a free notch and the leg won’t be torn off the body. It’s possible to move the bug’s body forward as well at any time during the turn if it won’t cause a leg loss.

When everyone finish playing cards – by verbal understanding cards can be played all at the same time or by turns – players discard them and draw the new ones. The game is over when at least one bug has passed the finish line by its body, which should be located at the three last track sections. If such a bug is the only one, its owner wins the game. If there are several challengers, the winner is defined by the location of legs.

Skillful players can play 4 cards instead of 2 during the turn. In that case each player draws 4 cards from the stack, leaves one in the hand and gives three to the next player, chooses one from the derived cards and gives two, and at last gives one and keeps another. By the way, players can choose the convenient design: there is a forest glade with an apple at the one side and a space station with a big red button at the other. Bugs are also two-sided, well-matched to the game field. Of cause, nothing impedes robot-bugs to land on the Earth as well as common insects can visit a space station, it will be even more interesting.

name: Sketchword
description: Think Fast! The clock is ticking! First make a word using the letters in your hand and on the Sketchword board. Then... sketch it! If someone guesses your word before time runs out, you score and so does the player who guessed. But each turn is a gamble in this game... do you go for a short, easy word for low points? Or do you take a chance on your drawing skills and try a harder word with a bigger reward? Sketchword is the best word game and the best drawing game combined into one box!
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Word Game

name: Dungeoneering Dolls
description:
Once upon a time, the world needed heroes. Brave souls seeking fortune and glory in the name of all that's good. Eventually, they gained whatever it was they sought and have retired. Too bad evil didn't do the same. Thus quests and monsters grew in number until, finally, Percival Thistlewood invented 2 foot tall wooden golems which, when clothed, took on the role of whatever garmets they wore. Initially designed for utility, the popularity of these Dungeoneering Dolls quickly spread throughout the kingdom and now you are one of many collectors attempting to create the best collection of Dungeoneering Dolls.

As a simple card game, Dungeoneering Dolls has two types of cards. The first is the quests, which occur at the end of the game, but the most cards are actually the Dolls. Dolls come in six classes and each class contains dolls numbered 1-8. These dolls are all worth a set number of positive or negative points. When you play them, you will stack like classed dolls on top of other like classed dolls. So any new Ranger goes on top of a previous Ranger, if applicable. There are also eight Limited Edition Dolls which may be played at any time and act as "rule breakers."

When someone plays a card, there is a chance for another player to steal it. To do this, they need to play a card of the superior class in an equal or higher level. So Berserkers beat Thieves beat Rangers beat Wizards beat Knights beat Clerics beat Berserkers. If a card is used to steal a card, they discard the card used and instead, claim the card they are stealing for their collection.

The game continues this way until the first quest is revealed in the draw pile. Then players resolve each quest one by one until the game is over. Quests will make demands like having the strongest Ranger. You'll discard the Doll which fulfills the quest to claim it and in the end, the player with the most points wins.

Each hand takes 9-12 minutes to play and a longer game may be desired, in which case, play to a set number of points. Percival Thistlewood's Incredible Dungeoneering Dolls was initially released on The Game Crafter in both Poker Sized and Tarot Sized card formats. It became a part of The Game Crafter's Village in a Box Kickstarter as one of the Microgames.

name: Полинезия (Polynesia)
description:
Cheerful Polynesians live where the sun always shines, the ocean creates vast noise, and the houses are right on the water. Not only are they skilled hunters and craftsmen, but also nimble traders. As the head of one of these Polynesian tribes, your task is to attract as many villagers as possible to your tribe. Market day takes place infrequently for the islanders, but when it does come, it attracts many merchants.

In Полинезия, you are attempting to purchase fish, turtles, masks, and flower garlands in order to hire patrons to your village and become the richest tribe in Polynesia. Each turn, the active player will roll four dive (each one with values of 1,2,3,4,5, and 8) that will set the market values of the four products for that round. Then, you will exchange your expensive goods for multiples of cheap goods, trying to get the best combinations of goods that let you attract patrons from the marketplace.

Your patrons, once 'purchased,' will come to your village where you will lay them out. As you progress through each of the three seasons of the game (there are three rows of four), you are trying to earn the most points from your patrons by stacking similar patrons, earning points from totem masks, and getting all three types of patron in one season. Your goal at the end of the game is to become the richest tribe in all of Polynesia!
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Chunky Monkey In the Middle
description:
Chunky Monkey in the Middle is the fast-paced, fill-in-the-blank party game where players match wits to figure out the Monkey in the Middle riddle. Think you know it?

In the game players compete against one another to solve word puzzles read aloud by one of the other players. Clues might be words or phrases like "Fur" and "of Paint" or "Dude" and "Dressing". The first player to figure out the connecting word ("Coat" and "Ranch") will grab for the squishy Chunky Monkey figurine and shout out their answer! If they are right they score a card, but if they are wrong the reader gets to keep the card. The first player to collect three cards that show "Chunky", "Monkey" and "In the Middle" on the back wins!

There’s only one right answer…but many hilarious wrong ones!

So get ready to go wild and get funky with the Chunky Monkey at your next game night!

-description from designer
categories: Action / Dexterity, Party Game, Word Game
publishers: Spin Master Ltd., The Good Game Company

name: Dead & Alive
description:
From the Designer of Maze of the Red Mage: A Solitaire Dungeon Adventure! and Tower of the Dread Mage:

Dead & Alive is a solitaire game of survival in a Zombie infested town. It is a stripped down travel version of a multi-player boardgame I created.

It all went wrong driving into town. A kid stepped out from between two parked cars. I tried to stop in time, but I couldn’t. I got out of the car and he was still moving. He was alive… but it was all wrong. His arms and legs were broken in impossible angles, but he was still alive and moving and… oh lord. I heard something and looked up, they were coming, all these shuffling people covered in blood and bite marks. Then the kid started squirming, teeth snapping… I just ran, ran for the nearest house to hide… the radio said some sort of virus had escaped, and the Coast Guard was ferrying people off the island. I heard a window smash below, I gotta find something to fight with. There are more of them moving towards this house now. If I can only get out of here alive…

In a town filled with zombies you move building to building looking for weapons to help you survive and maybe find another survivor to aid you...as well as roving packs of zombies looking to feed. The game is different every time you play and is only 2 pages. You will need the rules, 2d6 a piece of graph paper and a pencil to play.

You can download graph paper free if you look up my Tower of the Dread Mage Game!

Microbadges
Buy It

Buy It
categories: Exploration, Fighting, Horror, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Zombies

name: Zombies vs. Wrestlers
description:
Zombies vs. Wrestlers is the fourth game in the Army vs. Aliens series, with each game being playable on its own while also allowing for any faction in one game to be played against any faction in another or for multiple sets to be combined for team games or "last man standing" challenge matches.

As in the other games, Zombies vs. Wrestlers features two new asymmetric forces: zombies (lead by the necromancer) and wrestlers (lead by the Luchador). Each player takes one of the factions and rolls all nine dice. Taking turns, players then either attack the opponent or use a special power. Dice that are used are placed into the dice cup. If a player cannot attack or use a power, he instead "rallies", rolling the dice cup and simultaneously rerolling all of his dice still in play.

The zombie dice are unique in that they have no rank 4 unit, and instead have an additional rank 1 unit on their dice. However, they have several powers that revolve around gaining extra rank 1 units. The wrestlers have a more standard 123456 ranks, but have unique special powers involving "roll offs" and "tag team" plays.

name: Pixit
description:
Create order out of chaos! Pile up your Pixits, pick a card, and twist, turn and tip your cubes into place to recreate a pixelated image. This highly addictive, simple to learn game can be played alone, in pairs or in groups – hours of fun inside one little cube!

Pixit is for ages 6+ and can be played alone, in pairs or in groups. For two players, the Head-to-Head Mode urges players to pile up their Pixit cubes, pick a card, and then twist, turn and tip their 16 cubes into place to be the first to recreate the pixelated image shown on the card.

For Solo play, create images as fast as possible against the clock, and the aim is to beat your best time! Alternatively, the Memory Mode is for 2–6 players, in which one player is the builder and must recreate the image as the other players guess what is being formed. Each player has only one chance to guess what is being built, and if a player guesses incorrectly, they are out for that round. The faster you guess, the more points you win!

Whether Pixit is played in teams, in pairs or as a solo activity, each mode is exceedingly addictive and gets tremendously tense as the Pixit cubes twist and turn. With each game taking between 15 and 30 minutes to play, it’s the perfect entertainment for a long journey or a cosy afternoon.

—description from the publisher
categories: Children's Game, Deduction, Party Game, Puzzle, Real-time

name: Deserto
description:
Place a thief next to the treasure and it's your - Easy! But watch out for the caliph! To win, you'll have to play your card right in this tactical challenge!

Each players is dealt 3 cards, the rest of the cards are placed face down on the table. The top fours card is turned over and put face-up in the middle of the table. The playing area is formed by 4 cards laid out 2x2.

In each round, the player chooses one of the three cards in their hand and places it in the playing area. Then they pick up a new card from the pack.

One card cannot be put next to (vertically ou horizontally) a more powerful card: you cannot put a treasure next to a thief, or you cannot put a thief next to a vizier.
If the card put down is adjacent to one or two weaker cards, the players wins the adjacent cards or pile of several cards.

When the pack has all be taken and all cards held have been played, the game is over. The winner is the player who has won the most cards.

name: The Union Forever!
description:
This is the eleventh game in the Pocket Battle Games series from LPS, Inc.

Strategic level American Civil War on a postcard. The map of the Confederacy is divided into areas. The U.S player must strangle the Confederacy and reduce their will to continue fighting. Players use a standard deck of playing cards to activate armies (three Confederate and up to six Union) for movement and combat. Units can fight enemy armies in the same area. Combat is done by rolling 1D6, adding combat strength (for the Union) or Resistance Level (for the Confederates) and comparing results. Highest result wins. Losses are taken in retreats or in step losses.

There are up to eight turns, each of which is six months. The key mechanic is the Confederate Resistance Level (CRL). As Union armies occupy areas, the CRL falls. If the CRL falls to zero before the end of turn 8, the Union player wins, otherwise the Confederate player wins.

name: Insurgency
description:
Insurgency is a game of political and military conflict set in a fictitious underdeveloped province in the second half of the 20th century. The object of the game is to use guerrilla tactics in order to gain control over the country side.

Catalogue Description

Guerilla warfare, people's armies, wars of "liberation" . . . someplace in the world today, a campaign of Insurgency occurs. Set in a fictional province, somewhere, any¬where, this game lets the government and insurgents compete for local loyalties using companies and platoons of troops, cadres, bases, even economic improvement pro¬grams. You conduct a series of campaigns, simultaneously maneuvering forces and setting ambushes. Infiltration, control of key roads, pitched battles, even foreign sanctuaries and terrorist acts can play a role. Optional rules allow up to ten to play, introducing personality conflicts and obscure political motives. Insurgency comes handsomely boxed with a colorful 21.5 by 27.5” map, die-cut counters, and a rule book with basic and optional games, as well as comprehensive background notes on how this game simulates the truly universal rules of guerilla warfare.
Retail Price $12.95
categories: Modern Warfare, Political, Vietnam War, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Morgan's Rifles
description: Mayfair war gamette covering the Revolutionary War battle of Cowpens (SC). The "Rifles" were commanded by General Daniel Morgan.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Simulation

name: Pass It On
description:
A multi-player version based off of an ancient game, the players take turns removing tokens from one of their pits, and distributing them, one per pit, into the pits to the right.

Play continues until one person clears out all of their pits, or when all other players have filled their six penalty markers.

name: Three Player Chess
description:
Chess for three players on a hexagonal board. Includes a standard chess board as well. Designer may be Robert Zubrin, as he is listed on the box and rules as the copyright holder.

Edit: I talked to Robert Zubrin at the 2011 Mars Society conference and he mentioned that he designed a chess variant for three people. He should be listed at the designer.
publishers: Carter Hall, L'Impensé Radical, Nature & Découvertes

name: The Book of Greek Myths Pop-up Board Games
description: Four separate pop-up board games and a small booklet on the myths that inspired them. The games are The Trojan Horse, Odysseus, Theseus and the Minotaur, and Daedalus and Icarus. The book includes a spinner, different stand-up pieces for each game, and a small storage pocket.
categories: Ancient, Aviation / Flight, Children's Game, Mythology, Novel-based
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement
publishers: Savalas Publishers S.A., Tango Books, Σαββάλας

name: Ancient Empires: A Simulation of the Wars of Antiquity
description:
This is a different game from the Steven Mathers' Ancient Empires that's featured on this site.

This is a tabletop wargame using miniatures, which don't come with the actual game itself. It is based around the battles of Julius Caesar e.g. the Roman Civil war, the conquest of Gaul and so forth.
Contents of game box include: Gold Hot-Stamped leather ring binder, 100 page rule book, die-cut counters and color coordinated reference charts.

Expanded by:

Trojan Wars
Alexander
The Successors
Caesar

name: The Peninsular War 1808-14
description:
The Peninsular War is set in Spain and Portugal during the Napoleonic wars.The hex map represents a map of Spain and Portugal with most of the major towns and cities represented.One player takes the role of the French whilst the other plays the allies (Britain, Spain. and Portugal). Both players seek to control 8 of the 15 major cities at a set time period in order to win the game or gain an automatic win within the time scale by controlling 12 cities at any time.

A "do-it-yourself kit" version of the game (Watt's description) was made available in 1973; a more elaborate version (with wooden pieces) was produced in 1988 in an edition of 400 copies.

name: Der Rattenfänger von Hameln
description:
The players work together to find the way through the labyrinth and try to free as much kidnapped children as possible from "the pied piper from Hamlin".

Translation from the box:

A strangely dressed man kidnaps the playing children from the city Hamlin with his pipe. Hidden under the dark mountain, the little gaggle moan: "Nobody knows where we are. Nobody can free us!"

If we can find the right way through the tunnels, we can free them in a exciting rescue mission.

name: Critter Commandos
description:
CRITTER COMMANDOS is a game of squad level (and larger) combats that occur in a universe gone mad. All the combatants are modeled after Saturday morning cartoon characters, and that the damage caused by the weapons isn't really real! Each bit of damage puts a "hole" in the character (just like a cartoon!), and when they've taken enough holes, they are out of the game. But they come back for the next episode, safe and sound!

This game is intended to be a fast and fun introduction to the world of miniatures games. Each soldier has an INDEX that tells you how fast it is, how smart it is, how well it can shoot, and more. They also have a list of whatever weapons they carry. Using this, you as the player control how the battle unfolds, and try for ultimate victory.

The combat is quick-paced and east to learn. It uses a single roll on a ten-sided die to figure out any combat. The emphasis is on fun and excitement, not massive tomes of over complicated, supposedly "realistic" systems that bog down in too much detail.



In 1992 a supplement with roleplaying rules was released, see the RPGGeek entry Critter Commandos Compendium.
categories: Animals, Comic Book / Strip, Humor, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Hexagon Grid, Variable Player Powers
publishers: Monday Knight Productions, Team Frog Studios

name: Korsbækspillet
description: The game is a trivial pursuit, with questions about the danish TV-series Matador (1978-1981). It differs from other Trivial Games, as there is a stockmarket build into it. Its out of print and have been for many years.

name: Ancient Board Games
description:
Ancient Board Games is a collection of four popular board games which were played in the days of the pharaohs in ancient Egypt and in nearby countries from about 5000 years ago. It contains the following games:

Hounds and Jackals
Senet
The Royal Game of Ur
Mehen, the Snake Game

The games are presented in an oversized cardboard book with plastic playing pieces included.

name: Extreme Rock Climbers
description: YOU control your climber up the terrain of this mountain. It's over 2' tall! Special magnetic grippers that you wear on your fingers make contact with your climber's hands. Try to get to smoother paths if you can as flags mark how far you have gone. Position your climber on a hook if you need to plan you next move. But don't wait too long! After three climbs, the player who has climbed the most distance wins!
publishers: Drumond Park Ltd., Pressman Toy Corp., Simba Toys

name: Colossus
description:
Bonus game included in Dragon Magazine #271.

Through Research, Development, and Fighting, you must improve your creature until he has a 6 or more in each of his body areas - 2 arms, 2 legs, heart and head.

Equipment: Pencil and Paper, six 6-sided dice, at least five 8-sided dice.

From the intro paragraph:

In Colossus, each player is a mad scientist building some sort of creature. Perhaps it's a stone golem, perhaps it's a wicker man, perhaps it's a plain old laser-shootin' butt-kickin' giant robot. Whatever the details, you're building them, and you like to make them fight.

name: Think: Memo Story
description:
This is one of the the Ravensburger "Think" games, a brainteaser/mental exercise game-series.
These games are good for mental training, e.g. in creativity, concentration, imagination, logic and so on.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Memory, Party Game

name: Diversion
description:
This fairly ancient Racing Game (my copy seems at least 50 years old) has no dice whatever, an unusual feature for the genre. The gameboard has a series of turntables on it, which can be rotated so as to alter the paths in front of the players: the skillful manipulation of the turntables lies at the heart of the game. Each turn the player's piece (a small racing car) moves 1,2,3, or 4 squares forwards, at the player's discretion. If he lands on a space with black dots, he can rotate a turntable anywhere on the board, either to clear his path to the finish line or to hinder someone else. The Finish squares when reached give you points, and then you return to the start, only winning when you have 100 pts. It is possible to become completely trapped in an area with no black dots, and this carries a penalty of 20 pts and return to start.
The theme is pasted on, but the deduction and 'screwage factor' involved should appeal to many.

name: Bonsai Samurai
description:
Bonsai Samurai is a nano-game of a duel between two samurai. The game consists of a single card which serves as a somewhat chaotic spinner. The spin determines the players' options in a weighted rock/paper/scissors-style contest. Ties resolve differently depending on what was chosen, doing double or normal damage to both sides, or no damage.

The game is available for free download.

name: Bagration 1944
description:
A wargame about the final phase of Russian offensive in summer 1944. After the success of operation Bagration and destruction of German Army Group Centre, the Soviets advanced quickly towards the Vistula river and Warsaw. Already exhausted from the earlier fights and 500km advance the Russians encountered strong German forces pulled from the Italian front just when they were about to cross Vistula and capture Warsaw. At the same time the Warsaw Uprising began, complicating the German situation.

The game uses the "Wielkie Bitwy II Wojny 1939-45" or "WB95" (Great Battles of World war II 1939-1945) rules designed to simulate large battles of World War II. Counters represent regiments (Germans) or divisions (Russians), one hex represents 2500m, one turn represents one day.

name: Euro-Pack II: The Battle of the Bulge
description: Euro-Pack II: The Battle of the Bulge is a set of eight scenarios designed for the ASL (Advanced Squad Leader) system. Set includes Euro-Pack scenarios #62, 12, 52, 54, 53, 45, 10 and 20. Scenario directions are done in the standard ASL style, printed on heavy cardstock in black, gray (German) and green (American). Critical Hit describes this set as follows: "In a strange twist of corporate logic the gang at Critical Hit decided to present you an interesting set of scenarios depicting Bulge actions in Belgium, fought over places like Ligneuville, Cour, and Thirimont designed by...yes, Belgians! Not your ordinary Belgians, but the kind that walk battlefields and pore over every minute detail of the engagements." Like most ASL scenario packs, this is not a complete game and requires ownership of the necessary counters from other sources. Playing the scenarios also requires ownership of standard ASL mapboards/mapsheets N#1, 40, 18, 12, 24, St., 17, 19, 4, 41, 16, 18, 9, 18, 13 and 4.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Regenbogen-Land
description:
Regenbogen-Land (Rainbowland) is a children's cooperative game in which players roll dice to move through a fairy tale world to recover the colors of the rainbow that have been stolen by a witch. Players can freely give moves to help one another, and helping those who fall behind is essential because once players are halfway across the board, the witch starts to move and catch players.

Players restore the colors of the rainbow by placing colored plastic chips gathered during play on top of the rainbow at the center of the board.

The 2011 AMIGO edition is part of its "Ökologisch + Kooperativ" (Ecological & Cooperative) line of games.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Micronesia
description:
Micronesia is a tile placement, civilization building, area control game with role selection for 3-4 players.

Players are in control of the peoples of Micronesia. New islands are explored and settled, and new villages are created. Players choose roles which determine turn order and actions available to them for the duration of the round. Players earn points for the islands they discover and settle based on the traffic to and from the island and various villages grant the players extra abilities.

name: Monopoly: Fabulous Las Vegas Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Jackpot!

Buy, sell and trade the most popular hotels and casinos in Las Vegas right now! Wheel and deal Caesars Palace, Bellagio, Planet Hollywood, Stratosphere and the Red Rock in an effort to own and control the Entertainment Capitol of the World, Las Vegas. Become the "Kingpin" of America’s favorite board game, MONOPOLY, the Las Vegas Edition.

Includes 6 custom pewter tokens: roulette wheel, wedding chapel, stack of money, poker chips and showgirl.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: DIG: the Card Game
description:
DIG: the Card Game is an easy to learn and fun to play, tactical card game of hiring dwarves, provisioning supplies, digging tunnels, and mining gemstones for 2 to 4 players.

In the game, players represent Dwarven Mine Foremen. Each day the foremen hurry to the Provisioner to buy tools and to the Labor Camp to hire Dwarves. The Dwarves then set out to mine the dangerous caverns of an unexplored mountain. The mountain isn’t going anywhere, but other foremen are after the same gemstones. The Miners have six days (turns) to dig tunnels, mine gemstones, and hope to survive the day’s inevitable cave-ins.

The Goal of the game:
Players must carefully plan when and where to position their miners within their tunnels for the most successful haul of gemstones. At the end of each day, players may sell their gemstones to the Provisioner (at variable rates) and try to win the game by having the most Gold Coins at the end of the sixth day (turn).

The game includes the following mechanics: worker placement (dwarves), resource management (picks and lanterns), a light economic engine (valuable rubies, emeralds, sapphires, and diamonds,) and a dash of geological luck (random Cave-Ins).
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Black Stories Junior: Orange Stories
description:
One player reads the riddle on the front of the card.
The other players try to guess what's happened. The storyteller can only answer yes/no, so the other players have to ask the right (short!) questions.
The whole story is on the back of the card; it is read by the storyteller as soon as the other players have guessed how everything happened.

Orange Stories is part of the Black Stories series. This version's theme is travel and holidays, it's not about murder.
publishers: G3, Kaissa Chess & Games, moses. Verlag GmbH

name: Mind Your Marbles
description:
Each player uses a brain-shaped board that shows twelve categories. Next to each category is a hole in which to place a marble. The three-pronged spinner displays the same twelve categories, as does each card in a deck of trivia cards. Players take turns spinning the spinner and answering the three questions on a card that correspond to the categories that the spinner points to.

The twist is that a player cannot answer any of the questions until all three have been read; meanwhile, the other players spell out a sentence --- one letter per player --- that appears on a card that is turned over after all the questions have been read. Thus, the guesser is trying to remember the answers to three questions, while the other players distract him.

A player places a marble on his brain next to each category for which he correctly answers a question. The first player to fill all twelve holes in his brain wins.

name: A Way with Words
description: Each player chooses a color. Players then take turns placing a vowel tile of his or her color on the board until all the vowels have been placed. The remaining letter tiles of all the colors are mixed together. Each player then draws three tiles, and players alternate placing one tile on the board and scoring for any forward or backward words, including embedded words, created by the placement. Words of a single color --- your color or an opponent's --- score more. Each player replenishes his hand following the placement. Play to an agreed-upon number of points.

name: Arcane Legions: Egyptian Army Pack – Infantry
description:
From the box:

"Mark Anthony commands the combined might of Greece and Egypt, but the sorceress Cleopatra VII commands him. Together they field an arcane army like none that has walked the Earth, its ranks filled with undead from Egyptian tombs, creatures of legend, the mighty Roman 13th Legion, and even the ancient gods themselves - all barely controlled by powerful sorceresses."
categories: Ancient, Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Mythology

name: Castle Rising
description:
Castle Rising is a German-style board game in which you choose an economic strategy to try to create the most prosperous kingdom. Players acquire resources (food, wood, stone, metal and gold) to train troops and construct buildings to earn benefits at different stages of the game and victory points to win the game.

Players can acquire resources in three ways, the main one being through your peasants, with each player starting with three. You decide which resources to produce, but some are easier to get than others, so you can play it safe or risk trying for a few more precious resources. You can also gain resources through rangers, which you must first train, which takes several units of food and wood.

The last way to gain resources is through the bidding phase. Each turn, all players bid secretly on one of five different resource bundles.

name: Odious Lists
description:
In Odious Lists, players have a limited time to come up with answers to outrageous, irreverent, and offensive prompts... with all answers for a given round starting with the same letter of the alphabet. Points are only awarded for unique answers - with extra points for the funniest answers - so you'll have to be creative AND dirty. Which we're sure comes naturally to you given your sordid past.

The prompts have gone through multiple rounds of edits based on feedback from literally hundreds of play-testers. Our goal has been to determine the prompts that best allow players to come up with hilarious answers. To give you an idea of what we mean, here are a few of the prompts from the game:


I'd never date someone who is [blank]
Things you do when you're blackout drunk
Things found on the set of a porno shoot
Fox News claims that welfare recipients spend taxpayer money on [blank]
Words or phrases that could describe a sexually transmitted infection
The BuzzFeed piece "26 Ways to [Blank] Yourself" changed my life


Odious Lists comes with six sets of lists, several packets of blank sheets, six pens, a timer, and an alphabet die.
Each game comes with six sets of lists, with 24 different lists in each set
categories: Mature / Adult, Party Game, Word Game

name: 1653: Marineros y Mercaderes
description:
In the seventeenth century, the Caribbean, was an area little explored and full of adventure, where the intrepid crews traded and discovered valuable treasures.

Choose your crew, your cargo and weapons, and sailing in the Caribbean, seeking fame and riches.

In 1653: Sailors and Merchants, you will use your ship , which is represented by a deck of cards (which you will change during the game) in order to get the most possible fame points.


En el Siglo XVII, el Caribe, era un área poco explorada y llena de aventuras, donde las tripulaciones intrépidas comerciaban y descubrían valiosos tesoros.

Elige tu tripulación, tu carga y tus armas, y navega el Caribe en busca de fama y riquezas.

En "1653: Marineros y Mercaderes", usarás tu barco, que es representado por un mazo de cartas (que irá cambiando a lo largo de la partida) para conseguir la mayor cantidad de puntos de fama.
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling

name: Cogs in a Machine
description:
Gnomes, assemble! The factory is in dire need of your skills on the assembly line. Roll dice to amass parts, build components, and be the first gnome to finish their work and go home!

Of course, your co-gnomes won't mind if you borrow some of their parts and use your components to improve your work and mess up theirs, right?
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck

name: Race to the Top Australian Edition
description: Race to the Top puts your knowledge of every imaginable subject to the test as you scramble to climb to the highest level of the pyramid. You are in complete control of your fate, choosing the category and level of difficulty for each trivia question you answer. But be careful - your opponents will try to knock you off the pyramid!

name: Hedbanz: Headrush
description: Hedbanz: Headrush is a family party game, based on the original Hedbanz game. The quick question game of “what am I?” that leaves everyone guessing. This version is played in two teams. The fastest team wins. Contents include 25 Picture Cards, 2 Headbands, and Rule Sheet.

name: Lightning
description: Lightning is a fast reflex game that uses creatures from the Chinese zodiac. Players win by playing all of their cards before anyone else, with everyone playing cards simultaneously.

name: 1000 Voltios
description:
Objective: The objective is to be the first player to make an electrical instalation from the switch to the bulb.

The number of cards needed to be the winner without the switch, the bulb and the terminals depends on the number of players.

2 players 15 cards alt least
3 players 12 cards alt least
4 players 10 cards alt least
5 players 8 cards alt least

Components: A deck of 105 especial cards. 10 chips of isolation tape. The cards represent 3 types of cable or wire and shortcircuits.

name: Sweet Jenny
description:
Sweet Jenny is a gambling game played in the world of Théah, the setting of the 7th Sea role­playing game, and is inspired by classic card games. As a game itself, Sweet Jenny is a mix of poker, blackjack and three­card monte using it's own unique deck. It combines strategy, bluffing, mind­games and blind luck to create a chaotic and fun diversion for sailors, dock­hands and slumming nobles alike.

Each round, each player antes up and is dealt a single card facedown. The dealer also lays out a number of facedown cards into the middle of the play area. Over three phases, players secretly spy their own or middle cards, swap out cards, or discard their cards, in the attempt to manipulate the splay of cards. To win the round, a player must end up with the highest hand without going over 17.

The winner of the hand wins the antes. The holder of the most ante coins when another player has none left wins the game. The game gets more complex with unique role cards that give players more powers to manipulate cards and the board.

-description from designer
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Push Your Luck

name: mau mau!! Das Brettspiel
description:
Unlike the classic card game, Mau Mau - the board game is not just about getting rid of your cards quickly and saying Mau Mau - it's about get as many points as possible. Shouting Mau Mau doesn't end the game, but gives you 5 bonus points. Playing identical cards and some special spaces also wins bonus points. The game ends when all the spaces on the board are covered with cards. The winner of this fast-paced board game version of the classic card game is the player who scored the most points!

—description from the back of the box

Draw two on the 7, skip a turn on the 8 - the famous card game mau mau gets its own special charm as a board game. Anyway, if Reiner Knizia takes over the implementation.

Placing a suitable card on another, the next player must react - this is the classic principle of mau mau. The suit or number must match the previously placed card. Reiner Knizia has transferred this principle to the game board: tiles are placed on a path. The color or symbol shown must match the adjacent tile. Special fields provide surprise effects. And the classics such as "two draw" or "skip" are also present here. For the penultimate card, announce "mau"; for the last card, "mau mau" also applies. However: "mau mau" is not the end. But only when all fields on the map are occupied. This creates tension: the winner is not who got rid of his cards first, but who has collected the most points.

So it is important to proceed strategically and reach the special fields, because they certainly lead to the coveted point chips. In addition, you usually have several investment options.

—description form the publisher (translated)

name: Пришелец
description:
This game is asymmetric. It’s one player against the rest of the table. All players are Astronauts except for one of them who is an Alien. The Astronauts are weaker, but they are many, and everyone has a trick up his/her sleeve. The Alien is stronger, yet it is alone. Every round you roll the die, move your character across the spaceship and make an action. The Astronauts win if they kill the Alien and destroy its Eggs. The Alien wins if it kills all the Astronauts.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Square Grid

name: Paint Chip Poetry
description:
Let the paint chips be your muse!
With a pile of paint names at your fingertips, the poems practically write themselves.

Draw a prompt card
Consult your colors.
Make a poem.
Reflect. Express. Laugh.
Play another round!


UNIQUE CREATIVE GAME: Players draw handfuls of paint chips and a prompt card, then rearrange the chips to create spontaneous poems out of the color names.
WORDPLAY FUN: Composing a poem is easy and fun with this colorful and creative game.
ENDLESS POEM COMBINATIONS: With 400 paint chip cards, 40 prompt cards, and 10 variation cards, poems are sure to range from profound to hilarious.
GREAT FOR BRAINSTORMING: This quirky party game is also the perfect way to bust through writer's block.

name: Basra
description:
Basra is a fishing standard deck playing card game similar to Casino. The game plays with 2, 3 or 4 players. 4-player game are usually played in partnerships.

Each player is dealt four cards and four cards are played to the table making the "floor". Jacks and 7's of diamond from the floor are shuffled back into the deck and replaced. Players take turns playing one card to the floor and capturing cards if possible. When each player has played all four cards, the dealer deals out four more to each player, unless the deck is empty in which case the round is scored.

Captures can be made by playing a card of the same rank or a card that sums to two or more cards. Multiple captures are possible, for example a 10 would capture a 3, 7 and 10 from the floor. Queens and Kings do not have numerical value so the only way to capture them is by playing the same rank or a special card.

Players earn a Basra, worth 10 points, by capturing all the cards remaining on the floor . Players keep track of this by keeping the capturing card face up in their point pile. Jacks capture all cards on the floor, but do not count as a Basra. Jacks played on an empty floor capture nothing and remain on the floor. The seven of diamonds plays just like a jack except it earns a Basra if the captured cards add up to 10 or less. After the last card is played, remaining cards on the floor go to the player who made the last capture.

Scoring
The player (or team in partnerships) with the most cards receives 30 points. Ties are pushed to the next round (so 60 points could be earned).
Jacks and aces are worth 1 point.
The two of clubs is worth 2 points.
The ten of diamonds is worth 3 points.
Basra's are worth 10 points each.

A new hand is dealt unless someone has a total score of 101 in which case the player with the highest score wins. In case of a tie a new hand is played.

name: Harap Alb Continuă... un joc Love Letter
description:
Neris the goddess has left Earth a long time ago and quickly after forces of evil have started fighting for power over all mortals. Can Harap Alb, our last hope, collect the magical gems needed to open the portal that can bring Neris back? With the help of his friends, who all have super powers, he heads into battle against gods, sorcerers and other supernatural creatures.

Harap Alb continuă… is based on the mechanics of Love Letter, but its action is placed in a whole other universe and the characters are borrowed from one of the most popular Romanian stories of all times: the story of Harap Alb, the youngest son of a small ruler who proves to be smart, strong, and fearless.

Players start with only one card in their hand, drawn from a deck of sixteen cards. In each turn, a player draws another card from the draw pile – containing the cards that have not been dealt, and then plays one of the two cards from his hand, trying to expose his enemies and knock them from the game. Will you rely on powerful cards and jump right into battle, or are you building a plot using the weaker cards? But more importantly, do you have what it takes to help Harap Alb open the portal for the goddess Neris?
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Deduction

name: Fishing Camp
description:
From the rules:
The object of Fishing Camp - To be the first person to travel from the docks, catch a fish or multiple fish, and get back to the docks with their catch.

Fishing Camp is a roll-and-move fishing trivia game in which player move along a track trying to catch a fish before reaching the home space. All player start out at the dock with a fishing boat playing piece. They choose a level of difficulty from 1 to 4 for their questions. This is a way to handicap the game. Older or more experienced fishermen should choose a higher number.

Each player in turn rolls the die and moves along a track marked with lily pads. Green lily pads are safe spots. On a yellow (or orange) lily pad, the player must choose a question card and answer a fishing trivia question at their level. A decoder (transparent red plastic) is used to reveal the answer. If the answer is correct, the player rolls and moves again. If the card depicts a fish, the player keeps it and has now made a catch. If the card says so, the player may take the GPS card (of which there is only one), which may allow him or her to take a shortcut along the path. Purple cards may move the player to "Shore Lunch Island" or other locations, possibly delaying him or her. The first player to move completely around the track and reach a "Home" space with at least one caught fish wins the game. However, if a player finished without a fish, he or she may move immediately to "Last Chance Launch" and move toward the home space from there, attempting to catch a fish along the way.

name: A-Z Bilderquiz
description: 10 colourful pictures and an arrow to determine a letter of the alphabet - with these components from Kaleidos A-Z Bilderquiz offers several rule variants. In one game players try to be the first to name a thing on the pictures with the current letter, in the second game players try to find the majority of words and in the team-variant players name words alternately.

name: Perlentauchen
description:
Small, sparkling treasures are lying on the ground floor: colourful pearls hiding in shells. In Perlen Tauchen you play as pearl divers searching for these precious objects from the depth. You are salvaging and cracking the shells – but other divers are also on the scent of you and those pearls. To cap it all off you are struggling with the rough sea during your quest. The nacreous pearls reach their full value only when they join as chains, corresponding with your mission.
Your goal is to be the first to build the highly coveted pearl chains. The winner will be the pearl diver achieving that goal most frequent.

The shell cards lay down with their back side, like they were laying on the sea floor. There are mission cards for 2, 3 or 4 players, showing the required shell colors for each of the ten rounds. Each player has two action cards on his hand. In every turn a player draws a third card and plays one of them. He may either turn one card of his own or on the sea floor, or take it to his own shell chain in front of him or do both, take and turn it. There are also action cards to steal from another player or swap with another players card. In the case of a "flush away" or a "seaquake" the player must play this card immediately. In the first case he has to lay one of his cards back on the sea floor, in the second case all cards from the sea floor will be drawn to their back sides and shuffled again.
A round ends when a player has fulfilled his mission for the current round. Afterwards all cards wil be shuffled again for the next round. All players now should achieve the goal of the following round. The players may play up to 10 rounds. Who wins the most rounds is winner of the game.

name: Monster Mix
description:
Monster Mix consists of two games: "Monster Mix" and "Monster Express", both of which use cards that show monsters and cards that show only the top, middle or bottom of a monster.

In "Monster Mix", players each hold a monster card in hand and take turns adding monster part cards to the table, trying to assemble the parts they need to match the card they hold. If they do, they score 1 point and take a new monster card. Whoever scores 3 points first wins.

In "Monster Express", all of the monster cards are laid face up on the table, and the top, middle and bottom cards are placed nearby as three decks. One card from each deck is revealed, then players race to grab the monster card that matches the combination of cards shown.
publishers: Broadway Toys LTD, Happy Baobab, Mandoo Games

name: Kifkis
description:
Roll dice, challenge your logic and first discover the way to reach fantastic worlds.

Randomly distribute the Worlds cards on the table. Place a random Kifki on each world.

The two dice are thrown simultaneously, to find out which Kifki needs our help (hereinafter Active Kifki) and the number of moves they must make to reach the Right World. Immediately everyone will do the tour but EYE it has to be mentally, nothing to use your hands! When everyone thinks they have reached the Right World, they should touch the card with one finger. If the kifkif die shows multicolor, the first color that someone says will be the Active Kifki.

Kifkis always make the first move by going to the World Card of their color. Then, and if it is necessary for it to continue moving, it will continue its journey towards the World of the color of the Kifki with which it finds itself when landing.

The Active Kifki makes as many moves as indicated on the die, reaching the Right World. Once everyone has drawn a card, the course will be checked to see who gets the point. Whoever has marked the Right World first wins 1 point. In the event that no one has guessed right, no one will add points.
mechanics: Deduction, Dice Rolling, Network and Route Building

name: Rhett & Link's We're Still Good Game
description:
FROM THE GOOD MYTHICAL MORNING DUO: Dive into the world of YouTubers and bestselling authors, Rhett & Link, with this hilariously entertaining party game. It only takes 30 minutes to play for 4-12 players.

LAUGH IN THE FACE OF DISASTER: Score chips by playing the ‘best’ missing words in your hand and writing the ‘most optimistic’ positive spin on ridiculous disasters. No worries! We’re still good.

PERFECT FOR PARTIES & GROUPS: We’re Still Good is easy enough for anyone at the game night. Pull a scenario card, fill in the blank with a missing word card, then put a positive spin on a disaster.

You will receive scenarios like “You asked the tattoo artist to surprise you and now you’re stuck with a tattoo of ____” and more ridiculous scenarios. Score chips by playing the ‘best’ missing words in your hand and writing the ‘most optimistic’ positive spin on ridiculous disasters. No worries! We’re still good. This weird game is perfect for parties and large groups. We’re Still Good is easy enough for anyone at game night to play. Pull a scenario card, fill in the blank with a missing word card, then put a positive spin on a disaster.

—description from the publisher

name: Alchimech
description:
In Alchimech you are one of the ancient Alchemists, searching for the Elixir of Life. You are all on your own: the other alchemists are not always your friends, more often your competitors. Sometimes you can co-operate but local conflicts arise easily when interests collide.

Every alchemist wants to create the Elixir first, therefore needs specific raw elements from the four elemental kingdoms of Earth, Air, Fire, and Water.

name: Stockbroker
description:
Players begin the game with 1,000,000 pounds. A single pawn begins on the start space of a circular track. There are nine companies from which players can buy stock. Each stock price begins at one, the low, and each can go as high as twenty-one. Stock rises as shares are bought and fall as shares are sold.

A player rolls the dice and the space on which the pawn lands tells the player which stock a player may purchase. A player buys and sells stock in lots of one hundred thousand. Certain spaces allow players to buy stock in any company. Other spaces allow a player to draw a "Tip" which reveal which stock will change and allow the player to react accordingly.

The players decide before the game begins what will end the game but the object is to gain the most wealth. Ages 12 and up
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Thugs!
description: A tile laying game where you are building a maze and trying to move your pawn to an exit while trapping everyone else. There are several types of tiles (e.g., thugs who you can fight to take cards from your opponents; medics who can heal you; mole people, who help move you around to different parts of the maze; etc.) that make up the maze. There is also an action deck that can move you or your opponents around the maze, or reconfigure the maze. The first person out of the maze wins!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Tile Placement

name: Slicks
description:
Slicks is a car racing game limited to 500 copies that comes as a basic edition (with only paper sheets) or a premium edition (with wooden cars and 4-, 6-, 8- and 10-sided dice).

Your maximum speed is limited by the condition of your tires, the kind of space on which you start your turn, and the weight of your fuel. If you have bad tires, have a lot of fuel or are in a sharp turn, you are limited to a maximum of four spaces. On good tires on the straight way you may have a speed of ten spaces at a maximum.

Your car starts with proper tires, and you may choose to use the highest speed die. The actual number of spaces you move on your turn is evaluated by rolling a die (premium edition) or drawing a card (basic edition), so if you're unlucky, you may move only three spaces when rolling a ten-sided die, while another player moves six spaces although he was limited to a maximum speed of six (using the six-sided die). Reducing your amount of fuel allows you to reroll the die or add a number of spaces to your die result equal to your position (1 when you are the leader, 6 if you are the last in the field).

Your tires lose quality when completing a round, crossing curbstones, or driving into cars in front of you, so you may be forced to take the pit lane, refresh your tires, and take new fuel.

Slicks is probably the first racing game in which the condition of your tires directly impacts your maximum speed. Although some luck is needed, the strategy of when to make a pit stop or when to take a worse position to stay on a better space is important and makes Slicks unique in the category of racing games.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: City Explorer: Tainan
description:
City Explorer: Tainan contains 36 iconic location cards throughout the city. Plan a unique sight-seeing plan and compete against other players to create the best plan. Each turn, you first reveal two cards, then you may take two actions, possibly taking the same action twice. These actions are:


Secretly look at a covered location card.
Push and slide one column up or down.


Or you can pass and take a row of cards, which will be your finished travel plan used for scoring.

Should you take your time and search for the places you want to go? Or should you fix your plans and maybe mess with your rivals? Plan wisely and act swiftly since the perfect plan may be snatched by others!

name: ZIUQ
description:
A fast party game in which a player must read an answer among the available 300 and you must be the quickest to find a question.
But you must follow the game rules to do it!

HOW TO FORMULATE A QUESTION:
To be valid, a question must fulfill the following requests:
1: contain at least one of the four random words on the table
2: follow the special rule of the round, if there is one (example: "in rhyme" or "as in a theatrical performance"
3: be new: you are not allowed to repeat questions already made
4: of course, it can have the current answer, as its answer!

L’idea di base del gioco è molto semplice: il giocatore di turno legge una delle 300 risposte scritte sulle carte e il più veloce fra gli altri a fargli la domanda giusta vince la manche!
Ma ovviamente non è tutto qui: ci sono parole obbligatorie da usare, termini troppo ovvi da evitare e 20 bizzarre modalità di gioco da rispettare.

name: Escape Game
description: Find the code to open the electronic lock. To do this, solve the puzzle by finding the 3 good indices on the chips (color, object and food). You will need for this the help of your detective tools: black light, red filter, mirror.

name: Shit Happens: Shitty Ways to Die
description:
These cards are full of really bad situations, but you have to sort them according to the level of how bad the way of dying is.

All players start the game with 3 cards laid out in front of them. The player to the right of the starting player reads out a card from the draw pile. The starting player must then decide where the card fits into their set of cards according to the misery rating. If they guess correctly, they add the card to their set. Answer incorrectly and the player to their left may try.

Arrange 10 cards correctly to win the game.
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Poltava's Dread Day: The Great Northern War 1700-1722 AD
description:
From the publisher's website:

Poltava’s Dread Day covers a conflict that lasted nearly a quarter of a century (1700-1722), with two turns plus an administrative phase each year. The Summer turn is when everyone gets to work. The Winter turn is where great commanders take huge risks. All movement is a variable, impacted by leader initiative and a die roll. Sometimes, the troops will move far and fast. Sometimes they won't.

The game provides a range of different foot and horse unit types which impact how well they fight, but is unusual in one area—each unit is a single unit (strength of "1"), with no numbers to clutter up the counter. With few exceptions, once lost, units are gone forever...making each battle and each risk of attrition something to consider.

Poltava’s Dread Day provides a keen look into a decisive historical situation that few people know very much about. This period saw not only the founding of St. Petersburg but the birth of "modern" Russia. It saw the rise of Prussia, and led to shifts in the balance of power that would have significant effects on the Seven Years War.

Part of the TPS, "Decisive Battles" series
That means straightforward rules, key insights into the history behind the game, and designs aimed at one-session conclusions and high replay value. Poltava’s Dread Day features randomized elements for everything from reinforcements to diplomacy. No two games will play the same.

name: Myth: Crawlers Minion Pack
description: The Myth: Crawlers Minion Pack consists of ten crawler minions identical to those included in the base Myth game. These crawlers provide additional enemies that can be used to harass the heroes and spread the influence of the darkness.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Variable Phase Order

name: Geisterstunde
description:
Boooooo! In Castle Creepystone, the ghosts are restless. As soon as the clock strikes twelve, the ghosts begin their dance. They scurry all about the Great Hall, only to run into a a room. However, there seem to never be enough rooms for all the ghosts. And when the Witching Hour is over, a ghost not in a room vanishes.

Bits:
1 Board
15 ghosts
2 Dice
10 mirrors

Object:
The board shows the castle Creepystone with eleven rooms. Leading to the rooms is the Great Hall (around the perimeter of the board.) Over this, the ghosts run around trying to make it into rooms. Ghosts can takes shortcuts across the carpets to quicken their rush into rooms.

name: Count Down
description: Count Down is based on the Apollo moon mission. Players move around the board, Monopoly style, collecting and paying for various items necessary for their attempt to blast off to the moon (rocket parts, astronauts, fuel, launch pads etc.). Once a player has assembled his rocket and collected all of the other necessary components for the blast-off, an attempt to reach the moon is made. Just watch out for sabotage and espionage by spies from the other players.
publishers: Carlit, E. S. Lowe Company Inc.

name: One Night Werewolf: Super Powers
description:
One Night Werewolf: Super Powers uses the same gameplay as in One Night Werewolf, but adds new characters that provide fresh challenges.

As in Werewolf, players are dealt roles which are kept hidden for the duration of the game. The one or two werewolves try to keep their identity a secret so that no one identifies them; the humans must kill one werewolf or else their town is overrun and they lose.

Each player secretly gets a role card (with two role cards placed in the middle of the table), looks at it, then closes their eyes to represent nighttime in town. One player is the game's moderator and calls out the roles in order for the players to take actions. The werewolves and the CIA Agent(s) open their eyes to see who belongs to these groups, but they can't say anything!
