Each rating (pitching, hitting, running, fielding, etc.) is based on meticulous research and heavily influences game outcomes. These ratings, along with simultaneous pitch-by-pitch simulation and highly detailed charts and tables, afford gamers a wide spectrum of strategic options at nearly every turn.

The Ultimate Baseball The Game game box includes a basic version for youngsters and beginners which takes around an hour. Also included is the fully advanced and highly realistic game, which takes about as long as a real-life baseball game.

Ultimate Baseball The Game is for gamers age 11 and up.
mechanics: Role Playing, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Buddel Bande
description:
The rough translation of the title is "Digger Gangs"... and that's what each player represents... a gang of moles trying to find their way across the yard to their burrow without antagonizing the dog. (The pieces are top notch plastic-mold moles & a bright red dog.) Each turn you roll the dice, which tell you which mole hole you can next move to... and which size mole you must move. Now, you can move ANYONE's mole, since the only way to tell them apart is to pick them up and look at the bottom. (Something you get to do each time you move a piece...) Objective: get your three moles home first. (The dog is moved when rolled and can freeze a mole in position... but only one mole at a time.)

Intended as a family game, playable by children Ages 6 and up as well as adults.

name: Schlangennest
description:
Publisher's description:

Building the longest snake by laying tiles - easy rules, easy tiles, but not simple to play - for kids and adults.

name: Talking Stones
description: Talking Stones is a party game similar to Pictionary, where players are trying to get others to guess what the picture represents, except in Talking Stones, one does not draw the picture, but rather creates the picture out of what can best be described as gold-colored gravel.

name: Integralis: Die große Keilerei in der Buchbinderei
description:
"Integralis - The big free-for-all at the bookbinding shop.

Integralis is a game about the bitter fight to fulfill jobs. In this game, you are the leader of a project team in a bookbinding shop. Together with your team (your cards) you try to handle the mountain of incoming job. There are small orders, which are relatively easy to fill but yield only small profit, and big orders, for which a great deal of work must be done. Big jobs also bring big profits, however. The prize that our team receives for a successfully completed job is dependent on the number of tasks. However, the number of machines is limited and the competition among the teams is rough. No methods are shunned in the constant effort to keep away opposing workers or hinder their performance, not even bribery or sabotage. The only thing that matters at the end of the game is which team has the most money."
-From English rulebook

name: Scrabble Word Rummy
description: Two classic family games in one. Like rummy, players make groups of 3 or more cards. The cards are letters, and the groups are words. The longer the words, the higher the point score. Like Scrabble, players can score points by changing and adding to their opponents words.

name: Group Therapy
description:
Each player moves along a track and draws the appropriate "Therapist" card, performing the stated actions on the card, such as:

- Hold each member of the group in a way which shows how you feel about him.
- Pick a way in which you are phony and exaggerate it.
- Describe a significant way in which you use your friends.

After a player responds to a drawn card, everyone votes to determine if the player was "with it" (acted honestly) or "copped out" (was not open with the group). The player's piece is moved according to the results of the group vote.

This game was featured on an episode of "All In The Family" ("The Games Bunkers Play", Season 4, Episode 8) and has a definite late-sixties/early-seventies feel to it.

name: Railroad Dynasty
description: Rummy-like game in which players try to get rid of their cards by laying down "systems" consisting of U.S. cities and the (historic) railroads connecting them.

name: Fascination Checkers
description:
The board measures 10×10, with four 4×4 areas in the corners marked in a black and white checkerboard pattern (the remaining cross-shaped area is neutral). The black and white squares start off loaded with the black and white pieces. Black goes first.

Jumps are horizontal or vertical, over the opponent's pieces only. Multiple jumps are possible. Each jump captures the jumped piece. When a player cannot move, the other player keeps going until that player can move again. The game ends when no moves are possible by either player.

Whoever has the most pieces left wins.

name: Stock Car Saturday Night
description:
Print-'n'-Play game by Greg Poehlein brings stock car racing action to your tabletop! This unique racing board game offers cool components in a slick and compact board game design that captures the fast-action feel and strategy of small-town stock car racing in an exciting new way!

The game abandons the traditional oval-track-on-a-board approach in favor of a mechanic that emphasizes strategy and maneuver relative to the other cars on the track. Strategy cards held by the drivers put race tactics and skillful play in control of the result instead of just rolls of the dice.

Any good ol' boy can put the hammer down, but maneuvering through the pack, watching your tire wear and fuel consumption and knowing the limits of your machine are tricks only the best drivers can hope to master. When Stock Car Saturday Night is over, will you be up on Victory Lane making a hot date with the Performance Princess, or down in the garage gettin' greasy under a broken stock car?

The game includes printable PDF files for full-color counters, a two-section mapboard, turn and lap markers, and 160 strategy cards as well as a simple three-page rulesheet. Also included is a unique cardstock construct in the MicroTactix tradition -- a paperback-sized full-color slipcase storage box you print and assemble to hold all the game components, allowing you to display and transport your game after it is printed.

Web Page: http://www.microtactix.com/

name: Scrutineyes Junior
description: The game is played by drawing a card and then racing to see who can find 2 items on the list of 5 first. The items you find are on 1 of 6 large cartoon drawings.

name: Leagathon
description: This is a football game, the object of which is to acquire as much wealth as possible during regular season games and in the championship playoff games by making the vital financial decisions that mean the difference between profit and loss.

name: Frühling, Sommer, Herbst und Winter
description:
Spring, Summer, Autumn and Winter

In four simple games, 2-4 players Ages 4 and up accompany four fruit-trees through the seasons. Leaves, blossoms and fruits show how the tree is changing in the course of the year. All four games can also be played separately.

name: Word Madness
description: Your heart pounds as you race to make words of 4 letters or more duirng the Two-Minute Spellout. Opponents show no mercy as they madly snatch letters back and forth to form words, win points and go out first to win the round.
publishers: Great American Puzzle Factory, The Perfect Game Company

name: Hops
description: Hops is a game of the Heyne series published in the mid 70s. The goal is to fill the board with as many stones of your color by jumping opponent's stones. There is no capturing. Nonetheless, the game reminds of Reversi because of the filling-up of the board.

name: The Intruder Escapes
description:
The Intruder Escapes is a quick two-player game that was published in Intruder magazine #2.

One player takes the role of Eric, the Intruder, and the other player plays the monstrous Golden Hoarde. The object for the Intruder player is to cross the map and enter the throne room, thus avoiding the Master of Chaos and winning the game. For the Golden Hoarde player to win, he must attack at any opportunity, to force Eric to lose his six starting 'life points', rendering him unconscious and subject to capture.

name: Gal Master 1
description: In this game, each player starts with a set of 12 hero cards, numbered 1-12. The main deck of monsters is played one at a time, and each monster has a value (a few are even negative). Players then each play a hero card, and the high card kills the monster, and the player gets points equal to the value of the monster. If there is a tie, the highest non-tied character wins, so the winner when heroes rated 9,9,5,and 4 are played is the player who played the 5). At the end of the game, the player with the most points wins.

name: Operation Barbarossa: Moscow Winter General
description:
A World War 2 card game with mechanics similar to the same company's Monster Maker game. You play distance cards to represent the German's travel towards Moscow. There are enemy troops to interfere with your movement, and time cards simulate the passage of time (Winter saves Moscow!).

Includes rules for solo play, or works as a 2-6 player game as well.

name: King Hamlet
description:
Players move around Elsinore castle collecting the ten letters that spell King Hamlet.

Each player controls two pieces, a prince and a knight. The prince has extra privileges and if he is killed the player is out of the game.

Letters are collected by visiting the various characters - Ophelia, the ghost of Hamlet's father, etc. - on the board. Some locations are assassin's lairs; each player secretly locates an assassin in one of these at the start of the game and may kill a piece entering that location.

Each player also has one letter which is a "prince's secret" and can only be discovered if they are successfully dueled.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Secret Unit Deployment, Set Collection, Square Grid

name: Cromwell
description:
"Pouch" Series Game #8

Cromwell is a dual game, that is, two levels of complexity are provided. The game board shows a strategic map of England at the time of the First Civil war (September, 1642, to May, 1646) separated into counties and important cities, hereafter referred to as AREAS.
Is a two players game, but more players may be added. In all multi-player games, the Royalist supreme commander would of course be King CHARLES.
categories: Civil War, Pike and Shot, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Minimap Resolution, Movement Points, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Field of Honor
description: "Envision the age of chivalry. The time when mounted cavalry reached its greatest heights. An important part of this period was the contest of knight against knight in the joust or Pas des Armes. This was the time of iron men who rode against each other, lance to lance, to prove their mettle. Field of Honor simulates the Pas des Armes, or informal joust, of the high middle ages."

name: Final Days: Miniatures Battle Game
description:
From the publisher's website:

The Apocalypse is here!

The dead of the Earth have risen, and now they roam the land seeking living beings to feed upon. Powerful undead such as vampires and ghouls command legions of flesh-hungry zombies in chilling, inhuman war bands. Small pockets of resistance remain as humans wage a desperate battle for survival in a world where the waters have turned to blood and the sky is night everlasting.

Final Days is a complete boxed miniatures combat game where players command human freedom fighters or undead hordes in Earth's final battle! The combat system uses standard playing cards to determine the outcome of actions, and takes just minutes to learn. Play seamlessly with just two players or a group of eight or more! Everything you need to set up and play this fast-paced, hard-action game is included, and you can be up and running in no time. This boxed set includes Twenty-Five 25mm metal figures (8 different brand-new sculpts) to recreate your intense tabletop battles.

So grab your shotgun and bar the doors. The dead are coming and nobody is there to rescue you.

Final Days is a skirmish-level miniatures game that uses a standard deck of playing cards, with jokers, as its randomizer. Each figure has three attributes that determine how many cards it draws during combat, as well as determining how much damage the figure can take. As a figure takes damage, his combat effectiveness decreases. The game can be played with any number of players, and lasts on average 1 to 2 hours.

Box Contents

Rulebook
Scenario and Accessory Book
2 Double-sided B&W maps
Templates of burned-out cars, desks, dumpsters
2 Combat Trackers
Equipment counters
25 white metal miniatures:
Demon
Vampire
2 Ghouls
13 zombies
6 survivors
2 dogs
categories: Fantasy, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Religious, Science Fiction, Zombies
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: The Chick Game
description: The Chick Game® is a unique conversation game that encourages women to reminisce about lost loves, analyze the complex relationships in their families, discuss the ups and downs of their friendships, reveal their quirks, and dish the dirt. Unlike other "sharing" games, there IS a winner in The Chick Game®—it's the chick who reveals the most about herself, through a combination of choice and chance, during the course of the game. The Chick Game® rewards you for spilling all the intimate details of your life. But the game also gives you options to "play it safe" and answer less revealing questions if you'd rather keep some things to yourself. The Chick Game® is a great gift for women, and is perfect for birthdays, bridal showers, bachelorette parties, bridesmaids gifts, girls night out, girls night in, girls weekends, reunions, road trips, dorm rooms, and hostess gifts. The Chick Game® is "girls night out" in a box. It's available online at www.thechickgame.com.

name: Crete 1941
description:
"Crete 1941" is a wargame simulation of the airborne assault on Crete by the Axis in 1941. Study each type of piece carefully as you will find air units, ships and ground combat units employed the game mechanics.

"The map is about 10 miles per hex . . . The game on the ground is basically a battalion level operation."
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Simulation, Variable Set-up, Zone of Control

name: Sidi Rezegh
description:
In November 1941, the British 'Crusader' Operation was about to begin. The plan called for the breakout of the besieged Tobruk garrison and a link up with the advancing 8th Army units approaching Tobruk from the Egyptian border. Meanwhile, Rommel ignored the warnings of the Italian High Command and hoped he could deliver the knock out blow to Tobruk before the Allies made their next move. If they did attack, he hoped he could deal them a swift counter-blow and still take the fortress of Tobruk.

The game uses brigade, division, and regiment sized units. 110 counters (2 of which are blanks). Part of Excalibre's Panzer Battles and Sieges Series.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Simulation, Zone of Control

name: Q*bert Card Game
description:
Based on the video game of the same name, this card game has you build the highest scoring pyramid. Players have a hand of nine cards, draw a tenth, and then play one of their cards either on their movement pile, their pyramid, or an opponent's movement pile.

There are three types of cards, movement cards, pyramid cards, and a few special cards. The movement cards show one or more diagonal directions on the pyramid the player's Q*bert may travel on future turns. Once a movement direction has been chosen on a previous turn, players may add cards to build a pyramid one card per turn. Players may also play movement cards on their opponent's movement pile to send that player's Q*bert in a less productive direction, or waste another turn to change direction again. There are also special cards which stop your opponents movement, or put Coily, Q*bert's purple snake nemesis, around an opponent's pyramid. There are also helpful cards that either move a Q*bert to the top of the pyramid, or to allow free movement on the pyramid.

The finished pyramid is made of staggered horizontal cards.

Players play movement cards to change their direction on the pyramid until one player finishes the completed layout, and scores 100 extra points. All players total their points on their pyramid and the highest score wins.

name: There's a Growly in the Garden!
description:
From the box:

Players help each other plant as big a Flower Garden as they can and also help the Growlies find what they need most, so they don't pick and trash the Flowers instead. With some sharing of ideas and talking over of strategies, we will help change Crabby, Messy, Greedy, Stinky & Snobby into happier creatures. Sometimes we will need Scarecrows as well as Special Items such as Fruit Soap, Cornstalk Brooms, Gold Coins, Smiley Buttons and, best of all, some delicious Humble Pie. Guess which Growly needs what item! On each turn, a player gets two cards to play somewhere in the Garden. When and where to plant a Flower? Or put a Scarecrow? Or leave a Pie? Decisions, decisions. Each game unfolds differently, so keep on your mental tiptoes. Lots of play value for as many as 6 players.

name: La Beast
description:
The object of the game is to win as many bean bills as possible and to lose as few bean bills as possible and to avoid the treacherous legume-loving monster. Wager with bean bills and test your trump and bluff skills.

This is a packaged version of Madrasso's forced trump variant.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Set Collection, Trick-taking

name: The Great Escape
description:
This is a family game for two-Seven players based on the now legendary escape exploits of Allied Prisoners of War held by the Germans in the multi national maximum security prison of Colditz Castle, during the Second World War.
The object of the game is for each player (Escape Officer) to be the first to achieve an escape of one or more of his POW team. He can obtain rope, food, compasses, clothing, and wire cutters to achieve an escape. At the same time the German Security Officer is deploying his forces to prevent escapes.This is just like another game Escape from Colditz but has slightly better rules.

name: Vietnam Survival Tour-365
description:
"Experience the emotions and obstacles of the Vietnam foot soldier as you take your men on patrol through the bush of Vietnam! Created by a Vietnam Vet."

"This game blends strategy, emotions, and luck in which a player can win by surviving 365 days through a simulated tour of the combat soldier in Vietnam. There are few rules which will not be difficult to learn and will enhance the competitiveness when applied".

The mapboard consists of 365 numbered spaces. The object is to get to the end of the tour with the most grunts left alive in your patrol. The "educational" nature of the game comes from the terminology (as well as attitudes and emotions) that the designer has injected into the game. Each square bears a term related to the Vietnam War, and a small glossary folder explains what each term means.

Contents include mounted game board, 53 plastic grunts, 2 dice, 20 boonie cards, 1 POW camp, 4 plastic helicopters, 4 patrol cards, and the glossary. The rules are printed on the bottom of the box.
categories: Educational, Modern Warfare, Vietnam War, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Anagramania
description:
Anagramania is an anagram-based board game for 2 to 6 players. Unlike typical anagram word puzzles, the clues in Anagramania are not just the word or words from which the answer is derived. Instead, Anagramania clues actually provide a hint or definition of the correct solution. Here's an example:

"Sam rang a friend to find out why the letters he wrote were so confused!"

The object is to re-arrange all the letters of the keywords ("Sam rang a") - which are shown in bold italics on the actual clue cards - to form a single word that solves the clue. The answer is of course "anagrams".
For each game, every player has an 11" x 4" 'throw away' clue sheet containing twenty clues like the one above. There are 24 sets of six clue sheets in each game pack. That's enough for six players to play 24 separate games.

During game play, players conceal their clue sheets in special 'pockets' that allow them to see only one new clue at a time. In most board games players have to await their turn, which can be quite irritating if each player requires several minutes for his or her turn. That's not the case in Anagramania. In each turn, all players compete simultaneously to solve the same clue. No time limit is set at the start of the turn, but once any one player claims to have the answer (and has written it down) other players have just one minute more to complete their efforts to find the answer (timed by a sand timer).
By solving clues, players move pawns on a 14" x 14" play board. A correct answer earns forward progress - two squares for the first person who answered, one square for others. For a wrong answer, the player moves his/her pawn back a square; and for no answer, the pawn is left in its current position. The winner is the first player to reach the center circle on the board, with a typical game lasting about 45 minutes. The simultaneous method of play makes the game very exciting, and leaves no time for any player to get bored!
mechanics: Memory, Paper-and-Pencil, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Exorbitare
description:
The game is based on the energy levels within an atom, and it is played on a board representing the Periodic Table of the Elements. The squares making up the orbits are numbered according to the atomic numbers of the elements from Hydrogen (1) to radon (86).

The number of counters a player has depends on the number of players. Two players have eight counters each, three players have six counters each, and four players have four counters each.

Players take turns to roll both dice. The scores obtained on the dice may be used as a total, or as individual dice scores, to move the player's pieces to their best advantage. For each six thrown, the player may move one piece into play, and roll that dice again. The player does not have to move a piece into play unless he or she has no pieces in play already.

The players move their pieces along the track until they complete a circuit and land directly on a jump square. When a piece lands on a jump square it is elevated to the next highest quantum level. When a piece moves up a level, the controlling player gets an extra roll of one dice.

If a player's piece lands on the same square as an opponent's piece, Blatting occurs. The piece that is Blatted moves down one energy level whilst the piece doing the Blatting moves up a level. If a player's piece passes an opponents piece, Zapping occurs. The piece that is Zapped moves down one energy level, but the piece that Zapped it does not move up. A piece that is Zapped can Blat any piece that it lands on. Thus both Blatting and Zapping are subject to chain-reaction.

To win the game a Quantum Jump must be achieved. This is done by having a piece positioned on the yellow flash square, situated in the fourth energy band, at the same time as there are exactly half the total available number of player-counters in play.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Orca Games Ltd, The Board Game Company

name: Cabbage Patch Kids Card Game
description:
On most days, the Cabbage Patch is a quiet, peaceful place. Stumble Bumble BunnyBee and the BunnyBees buzz about, sprinkling their magic crystals onto row after row of ordinary cabbages. And it's these cabbages that magically grow up into The Cabbage Patch Kids! The BunnyBees carry all the Cabbage Patch Kids to BabyLand General Hospital. And from there, Colonel Casey, the Stork, delivers them to caring people like you. But today, Cabbage Jack, the mean old rabbit, is trying to make the Cabbage Patch Kids work in Lavendar McDade's gold mine nearby.

It's up to you to rescue the Cabbage Patch Kids from the mine and then bring them home from BabyLand General Hospital. The BunnyBees will help you as much as they can — pointing you in the right direction. Colonel Casey, the Stork, will help you too. Good luck!
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Nicht drängeln, kleines Stachelschwein
description:
Don't Push Little Porcupines - A children's game nominated for Children's Game Of The Year, players are moving the porcupines around, collecting spines as they go. You start with 3 porcupines and 8 spines, roll the die and move one of your porcupines. Depending on your roll or move, you either collect or pay spines to the bank, or to the other players. The first to get 18 spines wins.

A well regarded game, simple but enough fun for adults and great for children.

name: Blick
description: This game consists of a hand held plastic tray with a convex base with a small divot in the middle and a little plastic jumping bean (Mr. Blick) that is hollow with a small weight inside that moves to the bottom of the bean as it flips over producing an erratic motion. The object of the game is to get Mr. Blick to stand up in the divot in the middle of the tray by tilting the tray so that Mr. Blick flips end-over-end. The winner is the person who can do this in the shortest amount of time. Box says ages 3 and up.

name: Mal Mal
description: One more pictionary... may be, but this one is definitely the most original. Each player on turn must draw a very simple picture ... with his fingertip on his partner's back. You'll find out that it's not so easy to find out what is drawn on your back.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Party Game

name: Naval Wargame Rules for the Ironclad Era
description:
The object of these rules is to reproduce the tactics of naval warfare in the period 1860 to 1880. This was the time when naval architecture and warfare underwent fundamental changes. No longer the majestic lines of the “wooden walls”, now the three-decker with smoke belching from funnels looking out of place between the masks, the awkward shapes of the American Civil War vessels and finally the multitude of one off designs which prevailed until the start of the Pre-Dreadnought era. Tactics were dictated by the great variety of vessels and weapons available, (an homogeneous fleet being unknown) and sometimes by the restricted sea-space available. I have tried to reflect these problems and changes in this set of rules.

In order to play the game, players will require the following equipment:
Metric rule
Angle indicator
Cotton wool.
Turning circle (see Appendix)
Protractor
Damage Control Chart for each vessel
A pair of decimal dice When used as a pair 00 shall represent 100. when used individually zero shall represent 10. Models with removable masts for sailing vessels. Details of armor, armament, speed, dimensions (free board, length, breadth and draught), whether single or twin screwed for each vessel being used. Position of the vessels’ engines should be known as they are not always below water - if unknown assume them to be below water.
categories: American Civil War, Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame

name: Engine & Cars Matching Card Game
description: Collect enough cards to make several trains. Simple game and easy to learn. Could be classified as a children's game. Cannot find the year of release on anything within the game.

name: Mr. Bigshot
description:
Mr. Bigshot is a remarkable game because you really play the Stock Market. How is this possible? You go back in time - over the past 35 years - and pick from hundreds of choice companies as if you were there.

Financial information & ratings have been meticulously gathered and presented in a simple & concise way. It's the Stock Market in a time warp!

You start with 100K ($100,000) and your goal is to be the first to reach $1 million. You do this by playing the Stock Market one card at a time. Each game card takes you back to January 1st of a random year in time, where two companies are pitted against each other in a head - to - head match-up.

These are real companies, with real ratings and real data from the year listed. You must pick one the companies and follow your investment through the year, stopping each quarter to assess whether you want to sell your stock, or hold to the next quarter. The Fourth quarter marks the end of the year, and the end of your turn.

On your next turn, travel to a new destination in time by picking another card and playing that year through.

Home Page: http://www.mrbigshot.com

name: Vacuation
description:
A Pepys Card Game released after the beginning of World War 2 with a related theme. Subject of the game is the evacuation (hence the name of the game)of children from the large British cities to the calm and safe sites of the country.

Object of the game is to get rid of all his cards first.
Game consists of 44 cards with different letter codes and some extra cards.

The game is similar to UNO with the winner the person who empties their hand first. Players in turn discard Girl, Boy, Householder and Teacher cards, following suit until a Master card is played. Two packs are used to allow more than 5 to take part.

The starting player lays out a card which the next one in line must follow suit. If he can't, he picks up a card or changes suit with one of the master cards. Extremely tricky are the two extra cards: ALARM and EXTRA GAS MASK allow to take some special action.
categories: Card Game, Political, World War II

name: Options
description: From the Manufacturer’s website: Options - a game that will bring out your hidden talents. Humming, Whistling, Sculpting or Drawing, you will be amazed at what you and your friends can do! For a greater challenge try drawing with your eyes closed or use your other hand.

name: Sentence Says
description:
The components of Sentence Says are: 4 sets of oversized cards: vowel cards, consonant cards, action cards and steal cards, 4 oversized sand timers: 15, 30, 45, and 60 seconds and 1 oversized custom die.

The object of Sentence Says is to create a sentence out of letter cards that you are dealt, using each letter as the first letter of a word of your choice. For example, the letter "C" could become "Cat", "Could" or any word that you choose beginning with the letter "C".

So, if you were dealt a hand consisting of the letters: M,F,G,A,B,P, you could create the sentence: "Freddy's Billy Goat Ate Pancakes Monday"...or "Get Powder Because My Foot Aches!". You can arrange the cards in any order to create your sentence. But you are under a time limit and the time depends on how many cards you are dealt (anywhere from 5-7 depending on the roll of the die). There is also an action card that you must draw before turning over your cards. The action cards give you an instruction for completing your sentence, such as "Your sentence must be in the form of a question" or "Do not use a proper name".

Points are at the bottom of every card. You accumulate points by creating an acceptable sentence within the time limit. You can also wager points by stealing when an opponent misses a sentence.

The fun of the game is coming up with well thought-out sentences and hearing the silly sentences that people try to get away with (and of course, winning). It's perfect to play a one on one session or in a large group at a party.

Sentence Says is brand new game and is available at select specialty retail outlets or online at www.sentencesays.com
categories: Card Game, Educational, Humor, Party Game, Word Game

name: Gagline
description: "The Unique Cartoon Caption Game." Players take turns choosing a cartoon from the supplied books (4 duplicate books containing over 120 cartoons). All players write their own captions for the cartoon. The object of the game is to make your "gaglines" or captions very funny... in fact, to write the cleverest, wittiest and craziest gaglines you can think of. Chips are awarded to the best Gagline writers... the player with the most chips wins the game.

name: Death & Destruction: The Iran-Iraq War
description:
Design focuses on logistics and maintenance of units and command and control problems.

Contains 11"x17" color map, 280 color counters and multiple scenarios.

name: Name Dropper
description: What’s in a name? Winning the game! This game challenges you to get your team to guess the names of famous people and places on three levels of play: say anything, say one thing and say nothing. Otherwise known as shouting out everything you can think of, carefully choosing one word and charades. Sometimes it’s easy (you draw Daffy Duck and shout “Thufferin’ thuckatash!”), but sometimes it’s sure not (how will you get your team to guess The White House without talking?). The cool game unit shoots cards to you and keeps track of the time, too. Game comes with Name Dropper Unit (electronic card dispenser with a 30-second timer), 400 cards, 1 score pad and instructions.

name: UNO: X Games
description:
A Themed Uno Deck. This Deck has many special cards.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO:

Tailwhip: Choose who to draw 2
Alley-Oop: Reverse and discard all of a color
Lipslide: Skip and draw 2
Can-Can: Wild draw 10
Nuclear air: Wild draw 5
Dirt-Dive: Wild and discard all but 5
Fakie: Wild and all trade hands
Drop a Hill: Wild and draw new hand
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports

name: Tennis Open
description: A simulation of tennis, which come in a very big box full of nice components (tennis court in three different surfaces, players, net...).

name: Europe 1483: Asia 1483
description:
Asia 1483 is the second medieval game in the Empires of History line of strategy board games, and companion to Europe 1483. In Asia 1483, players assume control of one of sixteen different kingdoms or empires for control of all Asia. Players need to make strategic alliances, be shrewd military leaders, vie for control of trade from Europe and Central Africa, and build colonies abroad. Only a combination of military prowess, diplomatic influence and alliances, and foreign trade will allow one nation to emerge as the dominant power in the region.

Asia 1483 comes with:


Large 8 piece [thick red paper] game map, over 43" by 39"
20 Page rule booklet
1 Page pull out chart & nation information sheet
2 Sheets of playing counters



Plastic playing pieces not included, but needed for game play*


Expands:

Europe 1483
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Negotiation, Wargame

name: True Dough Mania
description:
Another very cynical game about Canadian business and politics in the Trudeau era. (Like The Great Canadian Pie, which see).

Players are owners of Canadian businesses who must deal with many topical events like Acid Rain, Free Trade and Metrification.

The ultimate cynical aspect of the game is that the winner is the first player to succeed in losing all the assets of his business to the Canadian Government.

name: The Battle of Camden, S.C.
description:
Medium complexity wargame of the Battles of Camden, South Carolina during the American Revolutionary War. Outnumbered, General Cornwallis and the British Legion Defeat the American Army of General Gates. 144 counters. Rare. Limited Printing.

From the Introduction in Rules Folder:

The BATTLE OF CAMDEN, S.C. game simulation has been designed to provide the game player with a maximum in historical content while also providing an entertaining format for those interested in the "Battle" game simulations. The regimental unit identifies, battle strengths, and battle terrain were researched in detail in order to provide as much realism as possible, and give the players the feeling of having been involved in that part of history known as the American Revolution. The rules of play and the condition of victory have been designed to reproduce the actual conditions under which the battle was fought.

When playing the game, remember that "winning" is a relative term. It is sometimes more enjoyable to play as the commander of the "weaker" army, and see if you can produce a better result than the actual commander did. In the BATTLE OF CAMDEN, S.C. game, the winner can be decided on this basis. The player who performs better than his historical counterpart gains a measure of victory.
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Wargame

name: Tatü-Tata!
description:
From the box:

Alarm! The bell has rung and the game starts.

If there are a number of dots on the dice, one's little fireman is moved: he puts on his clothes and collects the necessary equipment. Then he slides down the sliding pole and steps into the big fire engine.

If however on the dice the bell appears, the bell is moved on a square on the bell card and the departure of the fire engine comes closer and closer!

The engine drives up to the emergency once all the firemen are sitting in it. It starts off with special urgency once the bell is sitting on the fifth and last square of the bell card.

Once it arrives at the emergency everybody checks if the right equipment has been brought along in order to receive one of the certificates as soon as the work has been done.

Who will get the most certificates?

A competitive game, with game board on two levels and a real little bell. Game instructions also include a variant for co-operative playing.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Stratelite
description: The goal of this card game is to collect ore. To do this, one has to invest in ore exploitation and various other constructions (defense and attack ships or technologies) on randomly acquired satellites. When these buildings are operational, they produce some quantity of ore each turn that will be available on the building's satellite. The first to collect 50 ore and capable of holding on to it before his/her next turn wins the game.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management

name: Cthul-B-Que
description:
Your goal in this card/dice game is to capture and cook the most delectable Cthulhu Mythos monsters without losing life, limb or sanity. You win by ending the game with the most monstrous dishes in your Serving Area.

To play this free, downloadable card game you need: a bunch of six sided dice (ten or so), some tokens (beads, coins, etc., a Cthulbeque deck and rules (downloadable from http://www.invisible-city.com/play/42/cthulbeque) and (optional) two paper clips for each player.

Designed by Jonathan Leistiko of Invisible City Productions with inspiration from Molisa DiJacimo and Benjamin Gibbs.

Redesigned by brazilian team Loodo http://www.loodo.com.br/2009/10/cthulinaria-jogo/, known now as Cthulinária http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/62352/cthulinaria.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Horror, Humor, Print & Play

name: Galaxy Grid
description: Galaxy Grid is Free Print and Play simultaneous movement board game comprising of a grid playing board on which four tanks maneuver attempting to disable opponent tanks. All tank commanders plot the course and shot range before each round commences. As the Movement Round continues, tanks are disabled one by one, but no one is safe until the Shot Round is finished. At the end of the round a tank may be undergoing repair in a docking bay, or may be set up for eminent destruction in the following round. The tactical choices are endless. Where are the other tanks going to move? What is the shot strength? These are questions to be pondered before entering the movement and shot commands into the tank console. Command your tank to victory!
categories: Dice, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Travel, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Breakthrough at Gemehalo 1999
description:
On February 23rd, the Ethiopian military conducted a massive assault upon the Eritrean Gemehalo fortress. Over 10,000 would attack, many would die.
The WW1 style battle was fought with many very modern weapons. The vaunted defenses of Eritrea in the Badme area had been immune to enemy attacks for years. The fall of Gemehalo would spell doom to the Eritrean defense system. The question was, would it collapse? The game comes with a 11x17"map, 280 counters and rules in which morale levels will create success or failure. Game scale is nine hourly turns, company level. This was the key battle in the war and would define the war's outcome in the weeks that would follow. One side would break and run but which one?

name: Mercenaires et paysans
description:
A magazine game from Jeux et Stratégie #17.

A medieval fight with production between two or three sides where you win by capturing enough pieces (or killing the other side). Some units are all too ready to change side.

name: Golden Nuggets
description:
Limited Hand Crafted Edition created by Utah Artist Shirley Smithers. Design in the mid 60's, her family played this game with lots of fun. She published the game just last year with the idea that families that play together stay together. The game is set back in the 1860's. You are a Miner or you are an Outlaw. The object of the game is to have the most GOLD $ by the end. Miners mine and the Outlaws loot and rob the miners. Different spaces have either consequences or actions. There multiple gold mines to mine and are limited as to how many times they can be mined. Once mined Miner needs to go to the bank and make a deposit and get more mining supplies, if they can get to the bank without being robbed.
I am one of those kids who played it in the 60's and it is great fun.

Jef Smithers
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: The Wind in the Willows Game: Rivals, Robbers and Rivers
description:
From the box cover --

Welcome to an exciting new adventure for Badger, Toad, Rat and Mole. The swollen riverbanks around Toad Hall are buzzing as everyone tries to catch a runaway boat full of stolen booty. The world that Kenneth Grahame created has been delightfully brought to life within this unique board game. Based on the illustrations of E.H. Shepard the four playing pieces have been specially commissioned and are made in stone and resin and hand painted. The backdrop for their adventures is a specially illustrated game board. This game is a true collectors piece for lovers this timeless classic children’s story…

name: 101 Dalmatians Puppy Rescue Card Game
description: The object of this children’s game is to construct the longest line of rescued puppies. This is accomplished by bidding for either a Puppy card or a Cruella De Vil card as it is turned up from a draw pile. With a hand of numbered bidding cards the players bid simultaneously as each card is turned. High bid rescues a puppy and low bid must take a Cruella De Vil card. Once all the cards are won, and after subtracting one puppy card for each Cruella De Vil card held, the player with the longest line of rescued puppies wins.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based

name: Astrology: The Game of Prediction
description: This game teaches basic concepts of Astrology. It was designed by two Astrologers to be an easier way to learn the basics of Astrology and the meaning of planetary/star sign relationships. They seem to have done a good job at that, unfortunately, game play seems to be little more than "roll the die, move pawn, draw card". A nicely designed board, very unusual movement die (Very large 12 sided with one of the 12 signs of the zodiac on each side, as well as a loose ball inside) and a cool, 70's look to the game. An interesting product from an interesting decade.

name: Tegn og gæt exclusive
description: A team game where you pick a card which states your assignment which is to be drawn so that your partner can guess what your assignment is.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Paper-and-Pencil, Team-Based Game

name: Kongespillet
description:
Trivia game with questions on the the Danish kings and queens.

Awards

2002 Årets Voksenspil, Adult Game of the Year Denmark

name: Program IV Baseball
description: Small game designed to simulate professional baseball, consisting of just eight pages of rules and charts. No teams were included with the game, but rather instructions to rate teams based on real-life statistics. Games were then played with dice and the charts provided.

name: Quarrée
description:
A game for two players with a very light billiards theme, where dice are used to represent the balls. Most of your dice begin showing a single pip, which means that it can move one space. Once you move a single-pip die, you must then turn the die so that it shows two pips, which means that the next time it is moved, it must now move two spaces, but only in a straight line (unless it is banked off of the edge of the board). The final three faces of the die are not numbers but symbols that give the die special movement abilities, such as the ability to jump over another die. Once a die has been moved six time, it reverts back to a single-pip die.

The game ends when one player has managed to move a die into an opposing pocket.

name: Backstreet Boys Around the World Game
description: Players compete to be the first BSB (Backstreet Boys) fan to get all the way around the world. The player who owns the game begins by rolling the die (one side shows the BSB logo, each of the other sides shows a head shot of a different Backstreet Boy -- Nick, AJ, Howie, Brian, and Kevin). The player may advance to the next spot on the track (a series of BSB head shots forming a path around the earth), if she can successfully answer the trivia question or complete the task located next to the Boy's head shot on one of 60 cards. The categories on the card are "Name That Song!", "What Comes Next?", "All About the Boys!", "Perform!", and "Dare!".
mechanics: Acting, Roll / Spin and Move, Singing

name: Kick
description:
Kick off. The game begins! Storm - Fight - Shoot - Goal!

Kick is a soccer-themed dice game. Each player has ten dice. These are your field players. On your turn, you attempt to move your dice towards your opponent's goal. Measure your dice powers in a duel with your opponent. Move the ball through your dice rows until your chance comes to score.

name: Tiger I
description:
Tiger I is a Japanese wargame published by Tsukuda hobbies which is a game on the tactical tank combat in the western front.

This game has several scenarios which sees Allied vs. German tank to tank battles in the Ardennes to the end of the war in Germany.

name: Enemy Below
description:
This is a Japanese wargame of submarine warfare in the Atlantic during World War 2.

1 rulebook, 2 data sheets, 2 hexmaps, 2 log pads,
4 countersheets, 2 playaids, 2 dice

1 hex = 93m, 1 inning = 1 minute

This game uses call-marker system that Tsukuda first invented in Task-force series.
Escort ship cannot see submarines. And submarine cannot see escort because they go undersea.
But, this game doesn't use double-blind. Instead, this use call-marker.

name: SpellCaster
description: SpellCaster™ is a contest of wills between two or more magic users. The winner will be the magic user who employs his or her skills to the most advantage.
mechanics: Action Points, Point to Point Movement, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Groucho's You Bet Your Life
description:
"This new sensational quiz game gives you and your friends the opportunity of playing "Groucho's You Bet Your Life Quiz Game" in your own living room. -From the manual.

This trivia game is based on the Groucho Marx game show You Bet Your Life, which ran from 1947-61. Players (or teams) take turns asking trivia questions to the opposing team. The team answering make points not only for answering the question correctly, but also for spelling the answer in the alloted timeframe.

Game includes a mechanical countdown timer (60 seconds), trivia cards, an answer card, and cardboard letter tiles.

name: Offshore Oil Strike
description: Two to four players compete at exploring for oil, building platforms, and laying pipelines to bring the offshore oil back to the player's home company. Players take on the roles of either BP (Hull), Amoco (Bergen), Chevron (Rotterdam) or Mobil (Dieppe) in their quest for oil. As with other games focusing on offshore oil exploitation (e.g., Omnia's North Sea Oil), there is also the risk that storms will reduce production on, or eliminate, one's oil platforms. The first player to make $120,000,000 in cash is the winner.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Fairway
description:
A Golf game.
A 9 holes board, 6 playing pieces, 5 different dice (one for each club type), Bunker cards, Trouble cards, banknotes and a set of papers to mark score.
A hole course is divided into a grid of squares. The player taking his turn chooses what club (and then what die) he wants to use. He moves his marker according to the result of the die throw in direction of the hole, and so on until the piece lands on the hole square. He can move it vertically on the fairway, and horizontally or vertically on the green. He notes the number of strokes he used and the next player takes his turn. When everyone has played the hole, everbody starts the next hole, and so on until 18 holes are played (the 9 hole twice).
If the piece lands in a bunker, a Bunker card is drawn and executed. If the piece lands in trees or rough, a Trouble card is drawn and executed. If the piece lands in water or out of bonds, the golfer plays again (the bad stroke is counted).
Money is gained for different reasons (hole winner, par done...). The winner is the one who gains the more money. Alternative game makes the player who played the less strokes the winner.

name: Space Race Expansion Kit
description:
This is an expansion for Fantasy Unlimited's Space Race game. It is actually bigger than the original, with 63 pages of optional rules and new scenarios.

The new optional rules include

Delay mission
Production costs
Quality control
Safety
Altitude records
Duration records
Publicity
Advanced mission planning
Rescue mission
Budget cuts & overruns
Insurance
Espionage & counterespionage
New types of satellites

The new scenarios are

Original game with new charts
Space in the 1970s
Combining missions
Campaign game
Historical game (US vs USSR)
Business player (has to make a profit)
Solitaire scenarios
Mini-games (short scenarios)

Expands:

Space Race

name: The Game of Bombardment
description:
The Game of Bombardment recreates naval battle during the Spanish-American War. It is played with either 2 players, or four players in partnership. A spinner is used to determine bombardment values, and play continues until one fleet or the other is sunk.

Contents: spinner, 10 markers in each color, rules printed on game box lid, and a lovely illustration of shore-cannons engaging a naval fleet.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Stellar Journey
description:
"Far beyond the Milky Way, undisturbed for billions of years, lies a vast, cold cloud of molecular hydrogen, helium, and dust. Penetrating shock waves from a distant supernova or a close encounter with a passing star disrupts the cloud, setting its gases and dust in motion. Forcibly separated into numerous fragments, the gigantic cloud is transformed into an immense stellar nursery from which hundreds of bright, shining stars will emerge.

To play STELLAR JOURNEY: The Game, each player gathers "mass" to form three stars, plus "time" for each to evolve through all stages from beginning to end. The first player to complete the life cycles of all three - ending in a white dwarf, a neutron star, and a black hole - wins! Whether new to astronomy or a veteran stargazer, whether competing with family, friends, or classmates, whether young or old, STELLAR JOURNEY: The Game is certain to provide hours of wholesome fun, learning, and adventure!

STELLAR JOURNEY: The Game
Simulates star birth from nursery to end stages
Four levels of difficulty permitting players to compete at their own level
No regressive plays - lose your next turn, etc.
GAME CONTENTS:
Game board; game pieces; sixty colorful cards presenting a total of 300 questions at four levels of difficulty; and a booklet containing the rules of play, record charts, game objectives, match to the National Science Education Standards, image credits, and glossary."

Stellar Journey: The game was developed in cooperation with NASA'S Chandra X-ray Center and the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, and The Wright Center for Innovative Science Education, Tufts University.

name: The Blue-Light Manual: Wargame Rules for the American Civil War
description:
From the Publisher:

"These miniature warfare rules are designed for simulated combat between plastic or metal figures which represent a number of soldiers of the American Civil War. These figures are affixed to stands which are themselves grouped together to represent field organizations of the period."
categories: American Civil War, Book, Civil War, Miniatures, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Hidden Movement, Line of Sight, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Coffee Table Caverns
description:
From the KenMGames website:

No longer are the dark bowels of the under-earth the exclusive haunt of poor graduate students who are forced to live in their parent's basement. Now it is the realm of strategic battles, unearthly magic, and ghoulish fiends ... Just make sure you clean it up by 7:00 ... the Johnsons are coming over and we need the rec-room back!

name: I Spy In Common
description: All players fill in their game board using tiles that have something in common--across, down, or diagonally--within the three minute time limit. Jot down each common idea on the note sheets provided, then "sell" other players on your ideas.

name: Mister Zero
description: The board shows a network of roads, in the middle a character - Mr. Zero. Each player has his own goal space and ten chips numbered from 0 to 9 with which to influence the path that Mr. Zero takes. They take turns placing chips on the roads. When all of the chips have been placed, the decisionmaking part of the game for the players is over and that of Mr. Zero begins. Each time he comes to an intersection, he always follows the road having the lowest-numbered chip. This chip is now flipped over. If by the end Mr. Zero reaches a goal space, a player receives all of the inverted chips. The player with the most chips wins.

name: Knights of Old
description: Knights of Old is a wooden game. Players roll sticks much like Senat, moving their six "knights" across a "drawbridge." Landing on the opponent's knights captures them, increasing the size of that stack. When a knight or a stack of knights reaches the other side of the bridge, the opponent's knights are considered captured and the player's knights start again at the beginning of the bridge, ready to capture more. The game ends when one player's knights are all captured.

name: L'Échappée du Tour
description:
Each player controls a team of 3 cyclists. The game consists of 3 races - a prologue, a race of 1.5 laps and a final race of 2 laps.

Cyclists are moved by playing cards. There are some special cards (breakaway) and surprise cards (flat tire, sprint,...)

Some additional rules cover specific situations (staying "in the wheel" of another cyclist etc.)

name: Schummelchen
description:
A simple bluffing game for children. Give and receive pears from your pile. Guess who is giving you the wormy pear and receive good pears instead.

From the box: The players move on the pears from hiding-place to hiding-place. Watch out! There are little caterpillars in some of the fruits! In just three turns, you must exchange your pears: who will be crafty enough to pass on the pears with caterpillars in them without the other players noticing, and doing so collect plenty of good pears?

A guessing and cheating game with little green wooden caterpillars to count the turns.

name: Audition
description:
AUDITION is a family boardgame "combining the challenge of trivia, the fun of charades and an exciting race to become the winner of the much sought-after Golden Lovey Award".

In this roll and move trivia game players progress round the "Roll 'em" section of the board by correctly answering trivia questions, collecting token rings and assuming the role of the characters that can be found on "Rehearsal" and "Action Frame" cards. Players progress from the "Roll 'em" section of the board to the "Winner" section - the first player to reach the center circle of the winner section wins the game.

In line with the theme of the game the trivia questions are all concerned with movies and come in five categories:
- Action / Adventure /Thrillers
- Comedy
- General
- Science Fiction / Horror
- Westerns / War
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Malhação
description: In Malhação, players try to discover each other preferences. Each one writes down their favorite song, movie, travel spot, etc. Then players arrange meetings on the board and exchange confidences. Some places have special powers, and each player can lie three times during the game, so knowing whether to trust or not an information is very important.

name: All-Star Hockey
description: Cadaco's hockey board game, modeled after their baseball game.

name: Klik-Ball
description:
A simple dexterity game where players hit their ball up one of three inclined tracks with a small cue. Along each track are stops that "klik" when the ball passes it, stopping the ball from going backwards from that point. Each track has eight stops, breaking it into eight scoring sections worth from 0 to 50 points depending on where the ball comes to rest along the track.

After players have hit their ball up the track, the score is noted and players return their ball to the bottom of the track and begin again.

Klik-Ball may be played to a certain score (the first player reaching or exceeding a set score is the winner) or for a set time period (the player with the highest score at the end of the time period is the winner).

Klik-Ball may also be played solo, with a single player hitting each ball.

name: Prehistoric War P.I.G.s
description:
From the publisher's website:

The newest in the popular War PIGs (Plastic Infantry Guys) series, Prehistoric War PIGs uses plastic dinosaurs and cavemen as miniature figures in a high-action combat game where each player does their best to raise and maintain an army of dinosaurs. Tactics and strategy combine as players balance resource management and giant lizard mayhem.

For 2 or more players Ages 10 and up
.

name: Case Closed TCG
description: Based on the animated TV series, Case Closed is a CCG where players will prove that One Truth Prevails as their detectives face their opponent's criminals in the quest to solve cases. Gadget, clue, character, case and event cards combo together to unlock a game environment featuring danger at every turn. Solve these cases to win a match - take two matches and win the game.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Fliegende Untertassen
description: Using memory and alien movement (via dice rolls), players try to collect as many of the 36 face down tiles (UFO parts) and aliens from the board. Big UFOs in mostly the same colors that hold the most aliens score higher. The winner is the player with highest total score when all the tiles have been collected.
mechanics: Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Sorcerer's Apprentice
description:
An ever-changing checkers game for two players and an Icehouse set.

Object: To end the game with the most magic hats in your Hat Rack. Gain magic hats by capturing your opponent's pieces. You can put hats on your pieces to grant them special powers.

You Need:

* A checker board (pieces optional)
* An Icehouse set with red, yellow, green, blue, purple, and clear pieces. If you're not playing with checkers, you'll need two more sets (like opaque white and black) to act as checkers. These rules assume you're using checkers.

Play is just like a normal game of checkers with the following exceptions:

* If you see a capture, you must take the capture. If you have a choice between captures, you must choose one of them to take.
* When your opponent loses a piece from the board, immediately draw one hat from the Bag of Hats and place it in your Hat Rack.
* When you lose a piece from the board, you may immediately place one hat from your Hat Rack on any one of your pieces in play that is not currently wearing a hat. This is not mandatory, but optional. Hats confer special powers on the pieces that wear them.

Download Here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/81/sorcerers-apprentice

name: Stalingrad: A Walk in Hell
description:
Stalingrad: A Walk in Hell simulates the fighting for the western section of Stalingrad in 1942. The player controls – by moving counters across the map and combating enemy formations – the German and Soviet formations that fought in the battle.

Platoon-level simulation of the battle in Stalingrad with the city and nearby ground divided into areas. Players use cards to rally, refit, fire, and move their units, area by area.

The game was "published" in the September 2005 issue of Armchair General (it contains a key one uses to download a PDF).
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven

name: Ziggurat
description:
A domino-stacking game for two or four players.(But also plays good with three. See Video).
Object: To score points by stacking dominoes on other dominoes with matching numbers.

You Need:


A set of double-six, double-nine, or double-twelve dominoes.
Paper and pencil to keep track of each player's score.


Players compete by laying dominoes on the table to form the beginning 4x4 base of dominoes. As the players place the dominoes they score one point for every square on a domino that they played that matches an adjacent square on another domino in play. After the base is completed, players start forming new levels to the 'ziggurat' by playing each domino so that it exactly covers two squares on the level below it. Once all available plays on the current level have been filled (and not before), the players start a new level.

The game ends when all dominoes have been played or if a new level is started with only one valid place to play. Tally the points for each player. The player with the most points wins. If there is a tie for points, then the player with the least dominoes left wins. Additional ties are shared wins.

Download the rules here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/96/ziggurat

name: Lilla snigel
description:
Children´s game published in Sweden. Players are trying to reach the snail´s house in the middle of the board. When you turn a tile in your colour face-up you get one step closer to the house. Watch out for rocks and the bird.

The title, Little snail, is a song well-known to small children.

Wooden board, tile and die.

Ages 4 and up. Language independent.

name: The Impossible Game
description:
Roll dice as few times as possible to match symbols shown on the game board. Symbols must be matched in rows of six. Rows must be across or up and down. Each row of symbols must be matched in not more than 3 rolls of the dice per turn.

A player who has filled a row of symbols picks up the six dice and places a strip of cardboard over that row of symbols and continues to play, attempting to match dice with symbols in any of the remaining rows. The same player continues to play as long as he can complete an uncovered row of symbols. As rows are filled (or covered) the game becomes more challenging. Filling a row in the three rolls becomes more difficult. If a player does succeed in covering all the rows without ever giving up the dice, he has achieved the IMPOSSIBLE.

name: North Sea
description:
North Sea is another venture into the combined realm of education and entertainment, developed by Shell Oil. Its goal is to both entertain and to inform people of (and gain support for) the efforts to develop oil fields off the coast of Great Britain.

Two to four players compete at running their respective oil companies. Players will need to temporarily go into debt to bring oil production on line. The first player to have two producing oil fields *and* to be out of debt is the winner.

No copyright date is given, but the "Oil and Gas" writeup included with the game describes events that took place in 1973 and expresses hopes "that the Brent oil field will be producing oil in 1976." This places the game firmly in the early to mid 1970 time frame.

Waddingtons' "North Sea" is a different game entirely from the North Sea Oil offering by Omnia around the same time frame.

Components:

Game box and plastic insert
Mounted game board
Rules booklet
2 six-sided dice
3 plastic pipe-laying barges
3 plastic exploration rig bases
4 monthly-running-costs calculators (one per player)
4 sets of colored plastic pieces (one per player), each containing:
3 supply boats
1 exploration rig derrick
2 production platforms
1 refinery
10 personal markers
1 player token


20 Field cards
24 Chance cards
12 Loan cards
Play money in 7 denominations:
20 notes for £50,000
20 notes for £100,000
20 notes for £500,000
20 notes for £1,000,000
10 notes for £5,000,000
10 notes for £10,000,000
10 notes for £50,000,000


Shell information booklet: "Oil and Gas from the North Sea"
Information sheet on Robert Gordon's Institute of Technology
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Network and Route Building, Trading

name: Ephemeris
description:
Ephemeris (table of planetary positions) is based on the movement of the planets and the constellations they appear in.
Players move pieces representing the Sun, Moon, three Inner and five Outer Planets round a circular board divided up into the Constellations that form the signs of the Zodiac.
The players are dealt an open hand of cards representing the Constellations and a hidden hand of Planet cards, the object being to move the Planet pieces round the board to form your configuration.
Movement of the pieces is controlled by rules on which pieces can pass each other, with slower moving Planets being unable to pass the faster ones.

With all new artwork, in 2015, a 'new' edition of EPHEMERIS, A GAME OF ASTRONOMICAL STRATEGY, introduced an extra game-play for up to 4 players. Also, with the same strategy, an added set of Quiz cards was added making EPHEMERIS 3 games in 1 box.

The 2019 edition, EPHEMERIS, is boxed smaller, 23 x 23 x 7 cm. Board size is still 4-fold 44x44cm and the planet pieces are now of eco-friendly wood.
The quiz version gives you two options of answers, so a 50/50 chance of getting star points for your knowledge and clocking up your constellation points on the scorepad.

name: Met nijntje op stap
description:
Met nijntje op stap...
...naar het feest van tante Trijn

Aunt Trijn has invited Nijntje (=Miffy) to her party.
Nijntje loves Aunt Trijn. She puts on her most beautiful
dress, buys a present and goes on her way to Aunt Trijn.
While heading to see her aunt, Nijntje gets distracted by
numerous things, which causes her to forget about the
party.
Who's the first one to get Nijtje to her aunt's party?

name: Teddy Bear Look and Find Lotto
description:
The "Teddy Bear" Look and Find Lotto game has four busy picture boards of teddies having fun, and the object is for each player to be the first to collect all ten picture cards that correspond to his picture board.

Components: 4 picture boards, 40 picture cards.

To play:
1. Each player takes one of the four picture boards. The 40 cards are shuffled and placed in a central pile face-down.
2. The first player takes the top card, and tries to describe the picture in as much detail as possible.
3. If a player finds the describe card on his board, he takes the card and places it on one of the ten squares around his picture board.
4. The game continues until one player has filled all ten squares on his picture board.

name: Lilypad
description:
A checkers variant for two players.

Every spring on May Day, sprites and spriggans, dryads and trolls across the world all gather together in a secret place for the Unseen Revel--one boisterous week of music, merriment, revelry and sport. One of the most popular games at the Unseen Revel is a simple game called 'Lilypad': Two tiny fairies try to race across a pond filled with frogs and turtles without getting wet, and the first one across wins. To complicate things, one fairy is allowed to only step on turtles and the other is allowed to only step on frogs, and they start on opposite sides of the pond.

(Oh, by the way... If little sprites dancing on turtles and frogs is too fey for you, then just pretend that you're futuristic gladiators battling on hover drones over a pit of red-hot magma. That should get your testosterone pumping.)

The players attempt to move their pawns across the board without being captured. The first person to get his pawn across the board wins. If both players' pawns are captured, the game ends in a draw.

http://www.invisible-city.com/play/107/lilypad

name: Witch of Elsmea
description:
Elsmea, another world of warlocks and witches.
You are high school students at Academy of Witches.
A half year before graduation, doctress Diana invite all of you into her lab. "Welcome and congratulations, my bewitched girls!" She says " You are elected as candidates for the most valuable witch". Then, the elfin doctress adds niceties with gorgeous grin. "Only one of you will be laurelled as the Witch of Elsmea of the year. The winner should read ambitious message at graduation. Questions? "
"Doc," One of you say "what is standard for the examination?"
The instructor witch winks. "People of Elsmea know the way. They need fetishes or magick items for their poor lives. Go ahead and make their days happy! Class is dismissed."

Yes. Like the legendary witch who made glass shoes, pumpkin coach and mouse-coachmen for Cendrillon, you must create and use or give some magick items for citizen of Elsmea. Every 3rd month, doctresses check the folks' Favors of each region about you, and fill in report cards as Brownie Points (BP). Who can be the best? At the end of 6 months, the player scored highest BP win a game as the Witch of Elsmea!

To create fetishes, you must collect and fuse elements(clear colored beads) from all over the Elsmea (Game-map).
But your rivals aim same thing. And fusional process is static. Thus to win, you must control all things!
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Chit-Pull System, Memory, Pattern Building, Pick-up and Deliver, Set Collection, Variable Phase Order

name: Nemesis
description:
Nemesis is a (collectible) card game about gladiators, set in ancient Rome.
Each deck represents a type of gladiator (Myrmillo, Dimachaera and Retiarius decks were made) and the total of cards in a deck determine a gladiators total life points. Each turn a player takes cards from his life deck into his hand and attacks other players. Damage is taken by discarding cards from your hand or your life deck. The last player to have cards left in his/her life deck wins the game.
There is a pile of "Arena" cards as well that determine random events that occur in the Arena - some good, some bad.

Game was handmade, monochrome drawings on colored cardboard cards. Some 200 copies were made of the "basic set" (rules, Arena cards and two gladiator decks; Myrmillo and Dimachaera) and the "first expansion set" (Retiarius).

name: Tagina 552 d.c.
description: The battle of Taginae (552) between Goths and Byzantine during Byzantine reconquest of the Italian Peninsula.

name: Go For It
description: This is a very simple dice game with four different colored dice and grid cards. Players take turns rolling the dice and writing the roles down in columns. The goal is to be the first to complete a run of four or four of a kind in a vertical, horizontal or diagonal line.

name: Grabbin Dragons
description:
The object of the game is to be the player whose dragon collects the most magical ring using the tail-pulling mechanism.

Once you begin, you and your friend(s) race to hook rings on to your dragon's tongue, pull its tail so that its neck bends back and drops the ring into the ring container and repeat. You can also use your dragon to try and knock rings off the tongues of opponent dragons. Once all the rings are gone, count them up. Whoever has the most wins.

Because there are three different colors of rings you can easily institute variants where certain color rings are worth more than others.
publishers: Assim Toys, Chieftain Products, Clem Toys, Hasbro Industries (Hasbro Bradley), Ideal

name: Snookcard
description: A card game based on the table snooker ball game. Each player starts with seven card(ball)s. The top cardball from the deck is turned over and becomes the 'option cardball'. A player then takes either the option cardball or the top card from the deck and then places a card on top of the option cardball. A player may then make a break. A minimum break consists of a white cardball, a red cardball and a colored card ball (following the rules of snooker). As the red cards are played they are placed in the pockets in the snookard box. Later the colored balls will also be played into these pockets. A player replenishes back to seven cards. A scoreboard is also provided. The winner of the frame is the player with the highest number of points when the final black is potted. There are also special cards: miscue, snooker, foul, safety shot and free ball.

name: Professor Noggin's Wildlife of North America
description: Another of the Professor Noggin series of children's trivia games. The mechanics are fairly trivial: one attempts to collect question cards by answering trivia questions: in this case, perhaps surprisingly, questions about North American plants and animals. Each card has six questions by default, three each graded Hard and Easy. (The suggestion is that parents should choose Hard questions and children Easy when playing together.) The player rolls a d3 to select the question randomly. If answered correctly, the card is retained by the answerer; if incorrectly, the card is returned to the bottom of the pile. Occasionally, a card contains a special "claim a card from another player" action instead of a question.
publishers: Éditions Gladius International, Inc., Outset Media

name: Peak Experience: The Climbing Game
description:
A multiple choice trivia game based on the broad range of challenges and experiences faced by real climbers - from airport bureaucracy to the final descent.

Anyone can play Peak Experience - you don't have to be an expert climber. If you enjoy adventure and the outdoors you'll love Peak Experience. Come climbing on awesome K2. Travel through exotic Pakistan on the trek towards base camp. Use your knowledge, common sense and judgment to make it to the summit and back to base camp. As in real climbing, success takes both skill and luck. So whether you are a veteran climber or an armchair adventurer, reach for the peak!
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Team-Based Game

name: Kampen om Rai
description:
This game is included in a series of books called "Drageherren" ("The Dragon master", an easy-to-read fantasy series by Josefine Ottesen). The basic game comes with the first book in the series and the rest of the books will have small expansions to the game.

The basic game plays a little like the old Titan boardgame, with each player having secret armies on the map. Each player got one treasure hidden in one of his armies, and the goal is to get both of them to Rai (the capital in the middle of the board) and keep them there for 3 turns.

The two players will try to get his armies into the most favorable terrain which is different for each unit. Each army got one leader and two units (hidden at the start of the game) and the combat is simple dice rolling. The board is made in the same way as in Settlers of Catan, and uses hexes with various terrain.

"Kampen om Rai" was published as a "base" set in book 1. Followed by 10 sequels with 10 expansions total.
Some expansions inlcude more players, more cards and the "veteran unit" extra cards.

Book 8 opens for sea battles and sea monsters
Book 9 and 10 contributes with a boardgame map (poster-like)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Cup Skipper
description: "The match race sailing game" consists of 2 to 4 yachts sailing around a course set out at the beginning of the game. The game was developed to "to help improve interest and understanding of match racing" and consists of throwing a dice and moving pegs (yachts) up and down a board following yachting rules without incurring penalties.

name: QQChess
description: QQChess, a.k.a. Quad Quest Chess, is a chess hybrid/variant designed to accommodate 2, 3 or 4 players that combines features of international and Chinese chess. Knights can bounce off pieces of their own type to capture an opponent's piece. What's more, you can choose one of the opponent's pieces and have it become a traitor for your side.

name: Der Räuber Hotzenplotz
description:
Up to four players start from one corner of a square board to bring six figures into the middle of the board. There is the den of the "Robber Hotzenplotz", a figure well known in Germany from a bestselling children`s book. Every player has his own way from "home" to the "den", equally laid out, and at first sight without any interaction or connection.

But:

Instead of dice there is a turning plate UNDER the board. On your way some of the points you walk on are holes in the upper board. So, if you step onto one of those, your figure stands on the plate underneath. Now is the time to turn the plate and watch: Is your figure falling into the trap (the box), because the plate has a hole at the same place, or does it keep standing?
Through the same turning mechanism numbers change in small window-like holes, telling each player how far he is allowed to go.
One more point: Figures you jump over just don`t count. So, if you jump, you go one step further.

The first figure reaching the den gains six points, the second five, the third and fourth four and so on. The winner is the player with the most points in the end.

Looks like a pure game of luck, but the step on a hole also changes the numbers for the other players. There are more twists you have to think of (e.g. a shortcut through the dark wood etc.), so for young children this can be the gate to "tactics" and "strategy": Is my advantage worth the risk? And in which order shall I draw my figures? Because of the "jumped over doesn`t count"-rule, there are smart and dumb actions! And the winner is winning because of scoring points, not only, because he was the first!

Absolutely rare game and predecessor of euro-game-mechanics for young kids from the late sixties.

name: Loreley
description:
Being a sailor is not easy. If basic navigation wasn't tricky enough, approaching any bit of rock that sticks out of the water somewhere, inevitably means being lured towards your death by the mesmerizing singing of a local hair-combing siren.
