Loreley, sitting on her rock, surrounded by the Rhine, is one of the more famous ones, and the German mythology is brought to life in this simple family game. Getting your boatmen from the boats surrounding the rock to the safety of the Loreley rock and reaching the fair maiden itself is what this game is all about.

Loreley sits on top of her rock in the center of the board, dutifully combing her hair. The Loreley rock is surrounded by 32 boats, and each boat has room for two to four boatmen. Players will first have to get all their 12 boatmen onto these boats, before the race to the top of the rock starts in earnest, by moving boatmen from the boats onto the rock itself. There are four tracks on the rock, one for each player's color, and all are exactly 11 spaces long. When a player places the 12th boatman on the rock Loreley is reached and that player wins the game.

Players start with 2 of their boatmen already placed on seats in the boats. By rolling the dice, these boatmen are moved from boat to boat. When a boatmen lands on a boat that already contains sailors, that player can place as many new sailors onto empty seats on the board as there are present in that boat before landing on it. You can't land (or place) in boats that are fully occupied. When all of a player's sailors are in boats already, instead of bringing a certain amount of new boatmen into play, that player can start to remove that same amount of sailors onto the rock and when someone's last sailor is moved from the boats to the rock, that player wins the game.

The game needs 3 or 4 players to work, and is mainly aimed at families with children around 7-9 years old.

Publication history: this game first appeared in a full production with Pelikan in 1973. "Altmeister" Rudi Hoffman's return to the game industry after a long illness was celebrated by the republication of his family classic by Spielbox magazine (5/1986 oct-nov), as one of the earlier entrants in the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series. The graphics of both publications are showing their age.

name: Welcome Back Kotter Card Game
description:
Card game based on the popular 1970s TV show.

OBJECT: To be the first player to score 100 points by capturing Character cards with Kotter or the powerful Eighth Card.

The game replaces the traditional card suits with the four main student characters (Horshak, Washington, Barbarino & Juan). Kotter cards and School's Out cards are used for collecting scoring cards and blocking purposes respectively. The Character cards, valued 1-4, are used to determine totals when each round is completed.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
publishers: John Sands Pty Ltd, Milton Bradley

name: Medieval Wargame
description:
This 35 page booklet presents "Quick Wargame rules and historical commentary for the period 1100-1300 AD."

From the author's preface:

"Many sets of rules claim to be simple, and are so crudely simple they miss the spirit of bygone days. Others would swamp even Genghis Khan with their detail. This set of rules lets you fight a good-sized wargame in a reasonable time. Complexities that delay the average game are short-circuited here with a system of built-in probabilities. Though these rules lump some cumulative effects here and there, they nevertheless provide an enterprising general enough complexity to make games realistic."

name: Ordgeni
description: Guess the word using as few letters as possible. The fewer you use the further your playing piece may move. Throw the dice and let them show which combination of lids you may open, thus revealing letters. The one who reaches the finishing line first wins the game.

name: Monster Dice
description: Monster Dice is a game that uses extra dice from a player's collection to wage war. Each player is given a game card showing what type of dice are used in their fantasy army - and the back of other cards are used for the hex battlefields. The player who manages to keep their army alive the longest is the winner!

name: Professor Noggin's Medieval Times
description: What did the Magna Carta do for us? Who was Joan of Arc? How did one avoid being burned as a witch? Learn the answers as you travel back in time to a world of knights, battles, castles and cathedrals.
publishers: Éditions Gladius International, Inc., Outset Media

name: National Geographic: Pictures of the World Card Game
description: A simple trivia game on the topic of geography using cards with color pictures.

name: Show Off!
description:
From back of box:
Players race around the alphabet game board, as they flip over category cards and place their chips on letters. You can only put down a chip if you can name something that begins with the letter that matches the category card in play. You get 1 point for each chip you can place. Whoever has the most points after 5 rounds wins the game.

There are three different games to play, including an advanced game where players can bluff their way around the board.

Contents include: pencil, score pad, game rules, 6 chip holder boxes, Show Off game board, 100 Show Off category cards, and 180 colored chips in 6 different colors.

name: Timbuktu: Empire in the West African Sudan 1050-1550
description:
(from page 2 of the rule book)

Timbuktu is a four-player strategic-level wargame simulating the rise and fall of empires in the gold-producing regions of West Africa during the period 1050-1550. Each turn represents fifty years, more than enough time for several changes of monarch. Therefore, players are not taking the part of a king. Instead, they represent the changing political goals of their Tribe’s collective leadership.

Players will quickly realize that this is not a game where one Tribe can build an empire and hold onto it for the length of the game. Historically, as soon as any political system becomes set, decomposition begins. In short, empires decline. The effect of economic inflation and administrative inefficiency is built into the game. Victory lies in creating as glorious an empire as possible and cutting losses when it falls.

name: DragonRune: Arena of Death!
description:
DragonRune: Arena of Death! is a gladiatorial-style, fantasy, miniatures combat game designed for two or more players. The rules are simple and fast, with a wide range of options for gladiator design.

The Arena of Death rules are based on a modified version of Munera Sine Missione, but made to reflect the fantasy theme of the game with added races and size modifiers of the gladiators, and with a built in character advancement system.

The free rules and accessories are downloaded here:
http://hutchs-wargames.co.uk/Fantasyrules.html

name: Monopoly: Snoopy It's A Dog's Life
description:
The world's most famous dog and America's favorite board game, MONOPOLY, team up to bring you: Snoopy - It's a Dog's Life Collector's Edition. Snoopy has created a variety of memorable persona to capture your heart. Here is your chance to reminisce about all of your favorite Snoopy moments as you buy, sell and trade Snoopy's Joe Cool sunglasses, his Flying Ace goggles, his typewriter and the rest of his most valued possessions.

This completely customized game comes with collectible pewter tokens, including Snoopy's dog bowl, Joe Cool's sunglasses and Woodstock. A must-have for all Snoopy fans of all ages!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Track-Gammon
description: Track-Gammon is a backgammon-like game. Each player has five pieces of different sizes; the pieces must move out of the start in increasing order of size, but must enter the goal space in decreasing order of size.
mechanics: Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Inword
description: Players try to guess the word after they given a cryptic clue and the Inword, a series of consecutive letters within the word they are trying to guess. In turn, each player tries to guess the other letters contained in the target word. Players take turns as guessers and host.

name: Count your Chickens!
description:
Three games in one box.
Count-A-Doodle Dooooo!
The counting game that makes you count. Ages 3 and up.
Farm Five!
Be the first to find five farmyard friends. Ages 5 and up.
Barnyard Balance!
It's the challenge of the barnyard! Balance your barn before the rooster crows! Ages 7 and up.

name: 1812: Les Arapiles
description:
1812 Les Arapiles (aka Batlle of Salamanca in English) is a wargame / simulation of the battle of Los Arapiles on 22 July 1812 in Spain, near Salamanca. It is based on 1812.
The battle was a damaging defeat for the French Auguste Marmont and established the Duke of Wellington (leading the Anglo-Portuguese army) as an offensive general.

Scale :
- 1 counter = 1 brigade
- 1 hex = 350 m
- 1 turn = 30 mn

Magazine game in Casus Belli #41.

name: Political Football
description:
"Political Football" is a simulation of the infamous Rugby [football] Tour of New Zealand in 1981 by a racially segregated team from South Africa ( which was then governed by the Apartheid system of racial separation). The Tour was opposed by a coalition of anti-racist groups in New Zealand. The result was a watershed in NZ politics, as the previously peaceful and harmonious country was bitterly divided by the violence that resulted from the confrontation between these opposing elements. In particular, the NZ Police force emerged without its previous positive image as an agent of fairness and social cohesion.

The name “Political Football” is a play on the common expression in NZ and elsewhere, where a contentious issue may be referred to in this way, particularly where the original problem has a non-political nature but when there may be an element of political opportunism apparent. In the case of the Rugby Tour, as well as being literally descriptive, there was an element of cynicism readily evident in the controversy.

The Game

Game Play is generally intuitive, and the number of Counters ( total 21 only) means play is readily comprehensible as well as fast moving. There are no dice, but some small randomness in the appearance of some features earlier or later. There is only one “scenario” and the whole Game must be played to determine a winner. Time for whole Game is about 2 hours

The Game has four protagonists
1. The Demonstrators, who seek to disrupt the Tour to the extent that it must be abandoned
2. The Rugby groups, who seek to complete the scheduled Tour.
3. The Police, who seek to allow the Rugby to conduct their lawful business of playing Rugby
4. The Government, which manipulates the other Players, seeking to extract maximum political advantage from a Law & Order issue

Everybody except the Government has an inventory of Counters, which are able to move about the board under a movement allowance system, interacting with opposing counters. Players also have a suite of Action Cards which allow certain Actions to be played. Government uses its Turn to play certain cards influencing the other Players.

The Board is a stylized representation of
 four Sports Grounds, where the Rugby matches are scheduled ;
 a Court, where arrested demonstrators are processed;
 a Hospital, where “injured” Counters wait till released by Government.
 between these venues, a gridded surface of “streets”, across which the Counters move from place to place. Only one Counter is allowed on any one square; counters cannot “jump” other counters.

The Tactics of the Game involve each Player trying to
a. achieve certain mandatory objectives ( eg Rugby fielding sufficient Counters at the same time and place to actually play a match !).
b. prevent Opposing Players establishing themselves in such a way as to frustrate opposition objectives.

Progress is measured and the Game won, by accumulation of Points for performing certain Actions ( eg for Rugby ,“Play the Match”; for Demonstrators “ Destroy the Goal posts” or “Confront Police”).

In short, each Player can ( and must) adopt a mix of Offensive and Defensive play.
In general, all Counters can “bash” all other counters, putting them out of action for an extended but indeterminable time; while the Police have the power to arrest Demonstrators, removing them (briefly) from play. All counters can be also used to form defensive “walls”, preventing opponents from achieving their objectives (eg preventing Rugby Counters from getting to the Sports ground to play their game…).

These tactics will be familiar to anyone who has ever attended a political demonstration, particularly a violent one.

This Game has a number of very interesting features :
1. the protagonists are a-symmetrical in numbers, capacities and objectives yet play is finely balanced,
2. Both the Police and Rugby lose Points by attacking Demonstrators, but may lose more by NOT doing so!
3. While the non-Demonstrator Players have mutual interests, these are NOT identical – leading to subtle conflicts that preclude any lasting alliance.
4. The result see-saws wildly throughout the Game
5. Novice Players learn rapidly how their tactics need to change
6. No Player is ever permanently eliminated, which upsets novices !
7. Players offensive capacities are governed by non-recurring Action Cards : when to use them is a matter of judging opportunity.
8. Play often appears counter-intuitive to novices, but in fact is an accurate simulation of this particular variety of conflict, ie the maintenance of Law & Order in a democratic society where Police powers are limited by Human Rights considerations. Playing the Game itself demonstrates these principles powerfully.

In summary, this is a unique and workable game system that provides for very subtle calculations of both short term tactics as well as longer term objectives, within a simple set of rules.

name: Das Kapital
description:
The game "Das Kapital" was included in Spielbox 4/82 as part of the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series.

It is played on a triangular board with 81 hex spaces. It is a variation of a chess game for 3 players. And as in chess, the object of the game is the capture of the opposing king(s).

Each player has 9 playing pieces:

- 1 Kapital (similar to the king in chess)
- 1 Intelligenz (similar to the knight)
- 1 Kirche (similar to the rook)
- 1 Militär (similar to the bishop)
- 1 Politiker (similar to the queen)
- 4 Arbeiter (similar to the pawn)

The total number of playing pieces is exactly 1/3 (27) of the board size of 81. And since 54 spaces are empty at the beginning, a slower development of the game is achieved.

Several additions are made to the normal rules, like enabling the capture of own pieces (which allows an additional move) or making a putsch against the own pieces. It's not explicitly mentioned, but I guess, these additions can be left away to play the game.

name: Holy Hack: Hacking by the Book
description:
Holy Hack - Hacking by the Book (1996, Black Falcon Publications) is one of the "Hack" miniatures rules set, but this rules set specifically covers ancient warfare in the Biblical period. The rules are for either 25mm or 15mm miniatures, and while it recommends a basing system that is common with several other miniature rules sets (such as DBA, DBM, WRG 7th Edition, and WARRIOR), it allows for the use of any existing basing system the players currently use (an important consideration for miniature owners looking into a new rules set).

The rules cover the organization of miniatures into units, the variety of formations possible, and the importance of leaders and morale. Units are issued order chits (or blanks to confuse the opponent) at the beginning of the turn sequence, which commits units to specific actions for that turn. Orders are revealed simultaneously. The rules cover charges, movement, missile fire, and melee. Both missile and melee combat use damage tables with modifiers to determine casualties, which are converted into a percentage. Percentage dice (2 x D10's) are used to determine if a percentage fraction "hits" or not.

Although the rules use a casualty removal system, the most a side can lose is 3 figures per missile or melee round. Morale has a strong influence in the game, and the side that can force more morale tests upon his opponent will often win the game.

The rules come with a sheet of order chits/status markers, which can either be cut out or photocopied (using different colored paper can help to further distinguish the orders or unit status at a glance). This is not as complex a set of miniature rules as compared to Warrior: Miniature Wargame Rules for Ancient and Medieval Warfare 3000BC to 1485AD, but it can get a bit involved for new players.

name: Rocky Graziano Presents a Century of Great Fights
description:
Part of a 5 game series of Rocky Graziano (Boxing), Vince Lombardi (Football), Gil Hodges (Baseball), Rod Gilbert (Hockey), and Oscar Robertson (Basketball).

Historical boxers are grouped into two weight categories (light heavy/heavy and Middle to light) and rated on 8 different punch strategy categories, with 23 cards corresponding to the ratings (3 for each of first 7 strategies but only 2 clinches) plus an endurance rating. Players play hidden cards five times per round and there is a matrix for the interaction of all 23 cards. the die is only used on knockdowns. Because of the much wider variety of ratings, a fairly high difference is achieved for the 50 fighters included. Variations change some of the card interactions to eliminate possible "perfect strategy" which might be available in certain boxer combinations.
publishers: Research Games, Inc. / Athol / RGI / ARC

name: Skarbnica Gier
description:
"Skarbnica Gier" means "The Games Treasury". It is a compendium of abstract board games compiled by Lech Pijanowski - a Polish game expert and designer. The games he described are of three categories: traditional games (about 40%); modern games by various authors (about 40%, a lot by Sid Sackson); and finally his own creations (about 20%).

The package has a unique form of a double book. The left one contains the rules of the games, the right one the figures. Such a design simplifies understanding examples a lot! Four chessboards are added as separate inserts: 8x8, 10x10, 12x12 and a "domino-board" 6x12.

Chapters of the book:
- 8x8 board games (8)
- 10x10 board games (12)
- 12x12 board games (4)
- domino games (12)
- pencil & paper games (12)
- simple accessories games (6)
- sophisticated accessories games (10)

name: Italian Wars
description:
Two Player card game depicting a battle as fought in the Renaissance Era.

The battle is fought over a series of Hands. The first to win 8 hands or 3 in a row wins the field.

Period representative cards depict Leaders, Infantry, Artillery, Cavalry, Terrain, Morale, and Tactics. All cards interact in some way directly with other cards.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Print & Play, Renaissance

name: Play Fut-Bal
description:
Play FUT-BAL was designed and self-published by Willard H. Wendt, former Ohio University and Depauw University Quarterback. The game uses cards which depict plays to simulate football game. Includes Football field board and metal football, plus both offensive and defensive play cards. The game does not include a board, per se. Rather, the football field is printed on the box bottom. It is expected that you will punch small pilot holes in this box bottom with the included pushpin. The plastic football token for tracking the scrimmage line has a spike that can be wedged into these holes as you advance down the field.

The game is played by both players playing cards, one offensive, the other defensive. The strategy of the game comes from trying to force your opponent to play inopportune cards, such as ones that will cause a turnover, and guessing when they will play those cards, so that you can capitalize on it. Significant luck is involved, but there's also playing the odds through card counting and outguessing your opponent.

name: The American Revolution
description: The American Revolution is just one of the many cult classic games by Guild of Blades. Using the award winning "Empires of History" game engine this game can be played as if you controlled the entires armies under your command.. not just a battle or two. First in the Guild of Blades new "Signature Series" these are good games that play well and are as historically accurate as possible while leaving room for a player to deviate from history. The American Revolution is one of the pivotal points in modern history and the measuring stick for all revolutions to come. In this game you can choose to be the British or the Americans. Fight the war the way you would have done it from start to end and see if you make the outcome any different.
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Wargame

name: Bodycount: Wargames Rules for the Vietnam War
description:
Miniature wargame rules for the Vietnam War. Bodycount is for 2-6 players plus an umpire. The umpire controls the VC and NVA forces and these are not deployed on the table until spotted.

Expanded by:

The Face of Battle: The Hill Battles – Khe Sanh, Vietnam: 1967
categories: Dice, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Vietnam War, Wargame

name: Stock Block
description:
Stock Block - "The Original, Individualized Game for Any City"
[from the rules]

The idea of the game Stock Block is to purchase, trade and sell various stock certificates and stock shares (relating to historical, significant and economic landmarks in particular cities) in an effort to "crash" and "29" your opponents. Each player shrewdly conducts his "board business" in an effort to force other players into liquidating their stock shares and crash certificates when they do not have enough cash to pay the interest charges on their stock certificate squares.

Stock Block games now available for: Albuquerque, Atlanta, Baltimore, Charlotte, Chicago, Cincinnati, Cleveland, Columbus, Dallas, Dayton, Denver, Detroit, Fort Worth, Houston, Indianapolis, Los Angeles, Lexington, Louisville, Memphis, Milwaukee, Nevada, New York, Oklahoma City, Philadelphia, Phoenix, Portland, Richmond, Salt Lake City, San Diego, San Francisco, Seattle, Spokane, Twin Cities, U.S.A., Washington D.C., Montreal, Ottawa, Quebec, Toronto, Winnipeg, Vancouver, Barbados, Bermuda, Caribbean and Oxford.

Packaging, construction and distinctive game design are trademarks of J.F.M. Games Company's Stock Exchange Board Game, Registered in the US. Patent Office, Great Britain, Canada and Japan. Marca Registrada. Copyright 1976, 1977, 1978, 1979, 1980 by John F. Majors.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Nitty Gritty
description:
Nitty Gritty: The Star Game

If you are an eager beaver, here's your chance to get even steven with any funny bunny, providing you don't get into double trouble in which case any hanky panky could become hairy scary. So don't dilly dally, but get down to the nitty gritty so you can razzle dazzle without phoney baloney - and that, silly Billy, is super duper. Does this sound like mumbo jumbo? (From the box)

The game consists of 154 printed cards which, when properly matched with each other, make 77 pairs. Pair examples are: Mellow Yellow / Roly Poly / Plain Jane / Hebbie Jebbies...etc.

Each of the 154 cards has one word and from one to three stars printed on the face of the card. The number of stars indicates the value of the card.

The purpose of the game is to win as many matched pairs of cards as possible. When the stockpile of cards is gone, the player with the greatest number of stars is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Memory, Racing, Word Game

name: WooHiiWooHaha
description: The goal of this game is to build a pyramid of monkeys. There are three types of monkeys and all three types come in three colors. Per turn you can only build your pyramid in one color. When building the other players only see the back of each monkey, so they don't know the constitution of other players' pyramids. The only way to find out is to attack! And attacking is also necessary to keep other players from finishing their pyramids. Finishing your pyramid is a true feat of bananalympics.

name: John Drake Secret Agent Game
description: John Drake Secret Agent is based on the television show Danger Man from the 1960's starring Patrick McGoohan. The series would debut in Great Britain in October 1964 and would eventually find its way to the United States. In America the series was renamed Secret Agent in hopes of capitalizing on the growing spy craze. It was also given a new theme song, "Secret Agent Man," sang by Johnny Rivers. The game itself is a chase game where your secret agent tries to be first to catch the bad guys.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Political, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: John Sands Pty Ltd, Milton Bradley

name: Baseball Mania
description:
From the Rulebook:

BASEBALL MANIA... the boardgame represents an easily understandable and excellent analogy to the real game of baseball - without the injuries. A game is divided into nine innings. Each team is allowed a turn at bat per inning until three outs are recorded. With the third out a team's 'at bat' ends. The 'Visiting' team is up first each inning - considered the 'top' of inning. The 'Home' team always bats last or the 'bottom' of the inning. The team not 'at bat' is the defense. The team with the greatest number of runs after nine innings wins. If the score is tied at the end of regulation play, 'extra innings' are played until at the end of an inning one team leads. Runs are scored when a runner touches 'Home Plate' preceeded by tagging first base, second base, and third base. Not more than one player is allowed per base at a time. Runs, innings, outs, strike and balls are recorded by their respective markers. Strike outs are noted by the enclosed "K's" and are to be hung over the backboard when a strike out occurs.

name: Hinck
description:
Hinck is played on a 9 by 9 field board. Every player has 40 pieces, meaning that only the center square is unoccupied when the game starts.

The goal of the game is to get rid of your own pieces. You can do this by capturing your own pieces or by forcing your opponent to capture them. Capturing is done by jumping over an opponent similar to checkers. You must capture if you are able to. If you are able to make another capture after a capture move you must do so. (again, like in checkers)

You can only move horizontally.
Twice in the game you can skip your turn.

name: Show Me Yours, I'll Show You Mine
description:
From the box:

From the Inventor of Taboo, Outburst, and Malarky comes a new game.

It’s Simple...just write down 5 answers to the topic, then guess which of your friends have the same answer. Choose wisely…your points depend on it. It’s Revealing...some friends will match your answers...some won’t even be close. It’s Perfect for Parties...any size group will do. It’s all about a good time, laughs, and fun.

Contains:

6 viewers
6 dry-wipe markers
12 ALL IN chips
6 ME TOO cards
Wipe-off score card
One-minute timer
Topic cards

name: El Caballo de Troya
description: A two - player wargame in which one player controls Trojans and the other controls Greeks, and the objective is to kill the enemy king. The troops consist of infantry, archers, cavalry, and catapults. Every kind of troop attacks with determined number of dice and are moved with cards. There are also some troops that are used for reinforcements.
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting

name: Longstreet's Assault
description:
Longstreet's Assault simulates the attack of Major General John Bell Hood's division of Longstreet's corps against the Union left flank on the second day of fighting at Gettysburg, 2 July 1863. It covers the intense fighting at key sites such as Little Round Top, Devil's Den, the Slaughter Pen, and Bloody Run.

This is a tactical game where each unit represents either a regiment or an artillery battery. Each hex covers 125 yards. Restricted intelligence is used to simulate the fog of war and the oversized hexes are used to regulate movement. There are basic rules for the beginner and advanced rules for those that desire more detail. There is also a "what if scenario" of Hood's proposed flanking maneuver around the Union left.

name: Lawn Darts
description:
Lawn Darts is quite simply a game about playing lawn darts indoors.

Harken back to the good old days when you had a 2 foot long dart that you threw or tossed at a small plastic yellow or red ring. (and incidentally maybe at your friends toes or random appendages). Relive the summer fun with this quick mini reproduction of the game.

Please note... this is not the real thing... if you were to be playing this game... well there is not a foot and half long metal dart flying through the air. We use smaller magnetic tipped darts and our field of green is a felt field with rings backed by a magnetic strip. The essence of the game is still the same... get it in the rings. But if you want a bit of danger well we've included two felt feet as well... impale one with a dart and you lose points. Finish the round without sticking a dart into the tender tootsies... and you'll find your score climbs up a bit more.

If you have any questions... well I'm (mbourgeois) the guy to ask. We don't forsee production on this game anytime soon. There simply isn't the current market for it. However if you'd like to make your own... just ask for info and we'll send off the material requirements and measurements to make your own.

See: https://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2279107#2279107

name: CSI: Miami Booster Pack
description:
Be the first investigator to submit a correct arrest warrant, proving means, motive and opportunity for one of the three suspects.

Gear up for your next assignment, CSI: Miami Game & Booster Pack features three new captivating, original stories that can be played with the first edition CSI: Miami or on their own with the "Custom CSI Crime Solving Die" included in the game.

Follow lead criminalist, Horatio Caine, and his team of CSIs to collect the evidence, identify the killer and reveal the truth. Behind the sun, surf and palm trees lurks a darker world. You will quickly learn that each suspect is capable of deceit.

Expands:

CSI: Miami
categories: Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Murder/Mystery

name: Tamagotchi Electronic Grow Your Pet Game
description:
From the Press Release:

Based on Bandai’s popular line of Tamagotchi virtual pets, this board game allows fans to start out as an egg and try to be the first player to evolve to adulthood. An electronic “Tamascreen” selects players’ meals, toys, snacks and more, and Tamagotchi-themed challenges help players win.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Electronic, Fantasy, Video Game Theme

name: Caravan
description:
A pick up and deliver game where players trade goods and put up buildings. The 'robber' works against them as they try and build the most buildings.

The gameboard consists of an imaginary map showing four continents that are each divided into multiple countries. Every country is seeded with a token that represents one of eight different types of trade-goods. Players may pick up these tokens as they move their own pawn from country to country around the gameboard, and then collect payment for delivering the goods to a country where there is demand. Players spend their earnings to achieve a progression of game-ending conditions.

name: Gioca con me al Campionato di Formula 1
description: An old Italian racing game of F1. Move is spinner based. There is a plastic sheet where summarize, with counters, for every cars, laps, tire type, box stop etc.

name: Knights and Knaves
description:
Subtitled: A Skirmish-Level Game of Combat in the Middle Ages.

Mainly for 25mm figures. 1 figure=1 man, 1 inch=6 feet, 1 turn=10-30 seconds. Typically, one player controls around 20 figures. The rulebook comes with three sheets of Charts & Tables and a sheet of Organizational Chart (record sheet). 13 sample Organizations are listed.

Command Range (5 inches) is very important. In command figures choose Movement rate (full/half/no move). They are free to fire/melee. Out of command figures receive random Orders determined by rolls on a chart. Also, rules on morale, fatigue and ammo are included.

Later expanded by "More Knights and Knaves" (scenarios) and "Castles, Cogs & Chevauchees" (Siege, Ships and Campaign using maps).

All three now available free online.

http://www.hisentco.com/

name: Brain Quest: Know the States! Game
description: From the publisher: How well do you know the states? Well, you're about to learn all about American geography and culture in a really fun way! With questions designed by grade level, children from 3rd grade - 7th grade can all play this game together on a level playing field. Players move around the map game board and answer questions about cities, states, lakes, rivers, oceans, national parks, crops, industries, and more. When they answer a question correctly, they'll earn that state's flag. The first player to collect 6 state flags, wins the game. It's an exciting and educational trivia game that makes learning USA geography lots of fun! Comes with 440 Questions, Game Board, State Flag Tokens, Score Cards, 4 Pawns, Die, and Game Instructions. For 2 or More Players, Ages 8 and up.

name: Cornu
description:
The game has a plastic version of a cornucopia (horn) into which various objects are placed. There are 6 different objects: a wooden marble, a wooden cylinder, a wooden block, a bell, a metal marble and a piece of cloth. There is also a set of 40 cards which have photos of different mixes of the objects and also a '?' allowing for your own object.

4 cards are turned over and one player secretly chooses one of the cards and fills the horn with the objects shown in that picture. The horn is closed and the next player shakes it and tries to guess which card has been used by the sounds that are made.

The game is intended to develop the ability to pick out different sounds. The original 2001 prototype made by Reinhold Wittig (titled Das Füllhorn) had an African animal horn which was filled.

name: Tabletop Bocce
description: This is an adaptation of the lawn game Bocce or Lawn Bowling as a tabletop coin Flicking Game for the piecepack. Plays best with 2, 4 or 8 players in two teams. This game requires a seamless smooth playing surface of about 24x48 inches.

name: Brain Burn
description: This is a two layer solitaire sliding block puzzle, like an expanded version of the classic 15-puzzle, designed for the piecepack. The player is required to rearrange two different sets of values simultaneously, that move in different but related ways.

name: Clusters Word Building Game
description:
Notes on game from publisher:

This entertaining and captivating word-building game includes 100 plastic tiles in 9 bright colours, representing all of the common letter groupings. Players will discover that words are built with different letter patterns that represent different units of sound. Unique 2-tiered tile racks provide up to 4 players with workspaces to create their own words in preparation for play. Tiles include consonants, consonant digraphs, consonant clusters (blends), short vowels, long vowel digraphs and r-controlled vowel digraphs. The colour coding of each tile separates these letter groups in accordance with the Smart Phonics system.

name: Portfolio
description:
A set collection game in which players' melds earn them money. Cash can be used to draw more cards and to neutralize or steal opponents' melds. Players may extend or protect their own melds. Most money at the end wins.

The game is played with two or three ordinary decks of playing cards.

name: Palisade
description:
Palisade is played with a Go set. Points available to Player 1 are interspersed with points available to Player 2 in a checkerboard pattern. When you form a loop which surrounds enemy stones, you remove the enemy stones from the board. Neither player may place stones into a loop. A player owns the perimeter of his loop as well as all of the points contained within the loop. When all of the board points, both occupied and unoccupied are owned by the players, the game is concluded and the player who owns the majority of points wins.

Rule sheet:
http://www.marksteeregames.com/Palisade_rules.pdf

Online Play


Super Duper Games

name: Crazy Post
description: This is a party game which mixes word play with a hunt. The game involves posting the correct letter into the correct post box. The letters and mailboxes have similar spelled or sounding names, which makes the job quickly putting the right letter in the right mailbox more challenging that it would first seem. The winner is the person posting the greatest numbers of letters correctly. The game consists of eight cardboard post boxes and 384 letters.
publishers: G. N. Raymond, Party Games Publishers, Universal Publications Ltd

name: Touring Europe
description: Touring Europe is one of the travel board games by Geographia. Players start from London, and must race to reach their eight secret destinations located around Europe and return to London before their competitors. Along the way, players must negotiate customs checks and road blocks.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Open Whist
description:
"Before bridge there was whist, a much simpler card game to learn but nonetheless a challenging game of strategy for four players. Now there's Open Whist, a modern variation that two, three, or four players can enjoy."

Open Whist was originally designed so that two or three players could enjoy whist. In the two-player variant the players have two hands each. They are playing both the role of themselves and their "partner" in standard Whist. The main difference is that all of the cards are played face-up in a pattern that only allows certain cards to be played at any given point in time.

name: Quarterback
description: Billed as the "Computerized Action Game," Quarterback used a combination of offensive/defensive cards selected by the players combined with a small mechanical rolling piece to determine the outcome of football plays. Licensed by the NFL Players association, Quarterback invited players to play against each other as one of 16 NFL quarterbacks of the period.

name: Sexual Dilemmas
description:
Sexual Dilemmas is not just a fun game to play. It also provides for stimulating conversation and frank discussion that may lead you to know everything you never wanted to know about your freinds, neighbors and relatives. Sample questions:

HIS: Your 15 year-old daughter asks if you have been sleeping with the woman you are dating. If so do you tell her?
HERS: Your neighbors have invited you to a hot tub party. Some of the people you know, some you don't. You are the only one who has brought a suit. Will you take off your clothes?
categories: Bluffing, Mature / Adult, Party Game, Word Game

name: Game of Uncle Sam's Mail
description: Players move around the U.S. by horseback, stagecoach, steamboat, and railroad to deliver their randomly drawn pieces of mail. Each player takes one postman piece. The object of the game is to deliver 6 letters. The letters are first sorted into piles according to postmarks. Players then take 1 letter from each pile so that 1 letter will have to be delivered to each section of the country. Players either start in New York or San Francisco. The object is to deliver the letters to the various cities to which they are addressed. The game claims to have the best and most practical general railroad map in use.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: La Course aux Fruits
description:
Ah Fruits!

Albert the farmer is a very old man who can't really go around is farmland to pick is fruits like he used to.
So instead of letting is fruits rot on the ground, he gathered a few of his animal friends to help him out with his tedious job.

But if you give a basket to a duck, a dog, a pig, a turtle and a hedgehog, confusion is bound to happen!

With all of their good will and dedication, our little friends can't stop bickering and start little competitions between themselves to see who will gather the most fruits!
categories: Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Children's Game

name: Popppunktur
description:
An Icelandic (language dependent) trivia game about music. Based on a popular tv show and loosely based on another trivia game from 2001 called Gettu Betur.

There are 3550 questions and you move on the game board by answering questions correctly.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music, Trivia

name: Leatherneck III
description:
The third in the Leatherneck Series by Critical Hit. While the first two exclusively featured Marines vs. the Japanese army this third pack also features scenarios where various army units are fighting the Japanese army. Units include: Filipino 52nd Division, 763rd and 711 Tank Battalions, 77th Infantry Division and the 96th infantry division.

Contents:
8 Scenarios

Not a complete game by itself, this scenario pack requires ownership of modules from the ASL system to play.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Hypercube Hop
description:
Hypercube Hop is the first game from Brane Games. 2-6 players each take turns to move their individual wooden pieces one step around a flat representation of a four-dimensional space, collecting small stones as they pass over them. At the end of the game, the player with the most stones wins.

The appeal in the game comes from the simplicity of the rules and the different strategies that are needed when playing with different numbers of players. Advanced players will discover that careful negotiation can allow them to strategically "fence in" players who take an early lead, giving rise to diplomatic gameplay.

name: Hvis du nu var...
description:
A party game where the players are to guess what one of the other players would be if he was a specific object. For instance, one of the cards could read "If player X was a bike, what kind of bike would he be? A mountain bike, a racing bike, a three wheeler or a tandem?"
The other players will now simultaneously play a card stating what they think, and points will be awarded only to the players who think alike the majority.

Awards

2007 Årets Familiespil, Family Game of the Year Denmark

name: Billiards
description:
An abstract version of the game Billiards that can be played with the components listed below or on paper.

Each player places his three stones along the short end of the board closest to him.

On each turn, each player may pass or move one friendly stone. Each stone moves in a L fashion, i.e., it slides (orthogonally or diagonally) over a straight line of empty cells and just before reaching an obstacle (board edge or another stone), it must make a 90º turn (to the left of to the right) and move at least one more cell, until it finds another obstacle (it's invalid to stop in the middle of this double path). A stone already at the last row cannot move.

The player that first occupies his opponent's initial spaces with his own stones wins.

This game appeared in Walter Joris's book 100 Strategic Games for Pen and Paper.

name: IceFu
description:
This game treats white and black Icehouse pieces like the yin and yang of an I Ching trigram. Players create Icehouse trees with randomly drawn pieces and pits them against each other to fight. Last player standing wins.

Rules Link

name: Trice
description:
Trice is a game for 3 players that uses Icehouse pieces and a small, triangular gameboard. This game also uses dice. A set of 3 four-sided dice is recommended; however, if these are unavailable, the game can also be played with a pair of regular six-sided dice.

The object of the game is to occupy all of the spaces on the board that contain a specific mystic symbol. The 3 symbols are the sun, the moon, and the star. For each of these symbols, there are 5 spaces on the board that must be occupied in order to win. Two of these spaces contain only the one symbol, two are shared with one other symbol (these are called Bi-Spaces), and the final space contains all 3 symbols. (This space is the center space on the board, and it is called the Tri-Space.)

The complete rules are available at Wunderland.com.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: 101: The Win It All Card Game
description: Players play number cards adding to a shared running sum. No player may send the sum over 101, and a player is eliminated if unable to make any plays. Most cards are 1-10 number cards, but special cards include reversing the turn order, passing a turn, subtracting 10 from the total, adding 50, and setting the total to exactly 101. Players lose one of their three "101" chits when they cannot play, ending the round. After multiple rounds, the last player to possess any chits wins.

name: Punto límite
description:
The world in the decade of the 80's.

It represents the struggle of different nations for the supremacy across the economic - military power.
publishers: Factor Games, Nike and Cooper Española, S.A.

name: Ball Buster
description: Players move around groups of playing pieces set up similarly to checkers. Each piece consists of a plastic ball mounted on a long springy stem which is mounted on a peg which fits into holes in the board. Players can attack an opponents piece by pulling back on one of their own adjacent pieces and releasing it, causing the plastic balls to collide.

name: TKKG: Das Phantom der Nacht
description: The Phantom of the Night - there are some exciting cases to be solved, because the Phantom of the Night - the biggest crook of all time - appeared in the city. Before he can contact his assistants and get away with the car, the TKKG gang wants to catch him. But who of the 6 suspects is the true culprit? So TKKG sets out at night - when the phantom strikes terror into people's hearts - armed with a detective lamp, on their way to follow his footsteps, find clues and ultimately to unmask him.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Team Work: Mozart
description:
Mozart-related subject matter for the Team Work Original game. Like the other expansions in the series, this can be played as a stand-alone game or mixed with other decks.

Cards are in German, English, French, and Italian.

Expands:

Team Work Original
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Music, Word Game

name: Skat
description:
Skat may be played by 2, 3 or 4 players. It is similar in mechanics to Sorry! with dice in place of cards and marbles in place of movers. The players roll a die in hopes of throwing a 1 to leave their start space in the moulded plastic game base. Traveling the track of the board, it is a race to see who can get all 4 of their marbles into their home first. When you land on a space occupied by another player you call out "skat" and send that player back to their starting spot.

In a 4 player game, you can play as teams with the goal of getting the 8 team marbles back prior to the other team. Once a player has all 4 of his in the home spaces, he can begin to move his partners marbles.

Another version of the game is Wild Skat, using an extra hole in the center of the board. This extra hole allows you the opportunity to cross the board in fewer moves, but increases your chance of being "skatted" by your opponent.

name: War?
description:
From the One Page Wars game series.

An abstract, small-format "shoot-em-up" wargame with asymmetrical forces.

The mapsheet is a narrow corridor of irregularly shaped spaces made from overlapping hexes, some of which are marked as offering special defensive bonuses.

The black forces, which start at the south edge of the map, consist of three armor, three infantry, and three artillery units. The red player controls the northern half of the mapsheet, which holds the victory point hexes. The red forces consist of five infantry units and three artillery units.

All of the units are marked with two numbers. To prevail in combat, a unit must roll a result between these two numbers on 2d6. All units have the same movement rate, one space per turn.

name: Play on Words
description: "Be quick because each player only has one minute to “play on words” and win the challenge! Set the timer and, before it sounds, write as many connecting words as possible using only the letters on the eight cubes shown. The more words “played on” and the more letters used, the higher the score. Challenge friends or yourself with the solitaire version. Play On Words includes a built-in electronic timer. "

name: Intersect
description:
Intersect is a placement and capture game, with each player having two stashes of 15 Icehouse pyramids and four sets of four cards numbered 1-4 (regular playing cards will suffice, with the aces standing in for 1). Players sit adjacent to your opponent, facing at a right angle, rather than opposite their opponent.

Rules can be found at the Looney Pyramids Wiki.

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: Poosh-M-Up Slugger Baseball Game
description:
Poosh-M-Up Slugger Baseball Game. Manufactured in 1946 by Northwestern Products Co. of St. Louis, Missouri. Pinball style/ bagatelle-type. Fun to play! Simple design. The balls load under the pitcher's mound and are released one by one by using one of the controls. The bat works like a flipper in a pinball game. Wooden frame, glass top. 14 X 21 inches.

This game from 1946 is sort of a bagatelle game but can be played by two players. One player acts as the pitcher and uses the plastic pitchers spot to dispense a round metal ball (the baseball) towards the batter who has a bat which by pushing a lever, swings at the released ball in an attempt to make contact with the ball. There are a number of slots where the ball can wind up, scoring singles, doubles, triples and home runs. Double plays are possible and any ball not winding up in a slot after it is struck 1 time is considered and out.

name: Salvation!
description:
THE SETTING.
The decimating wars of the early 21st century have destroyed the great civilizations of the world, and humanity survives in pockets around the globe, living in barbarism and ignorance. By the end of the 25th century the world has largely healed from the holocaust, and the great religions of old, long surviving in their ancient strongholds, now dare to venture out once more to reconvert the lost.

THE PLAYERS.
Judaism
Buddhism
Orthodoxy
Hinduism
Roman Catholicism
Islam
Zen-Shinto
Protestantism
Taoism

Each tradition has its own special skills, its advantages and disadvantages in play.

VICTORY CONDITIONS
Your task is to control the spread of your religion by sending out missionaries, converting unbelievers, building new holy places, and bring at least a million souls into “Salvation!”

The game contains variants for 2,3,4,5, players and the full game, non variant, can be played with 5--9 players.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Civilization, Educational, Exploration, Religious, Territory Building

name: Hannibal Ante Portas
description:
Game about 2nd Punic War.

Strategic-operational scale: units are infantry, cavalry, elephants and navy, 1 day per game turn. Battles are played on separate board.
Each month is economical phase: players gain taxes from hold towns and spend them for upkeep and recruitment of forces.

Probably this game was an inspiration for Robert Zak to create his game Hannibal Barkas almost 15 years later.

name: Ancient Generals
description: Each player is a general fielding an ancient army represented by the cards in their respective decks. The game includes a deck of 100 cards, composed of 60 Tactics cards and 40 Unit cards. Each player is dealt 50 cards to start the game. The object is to destroy your opponent’s army by causing him to run out of cards. A player loses once he has no more cards left in his deck or reserve pile.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Take That

name: Baron Munchausen
description:
“Card game for Aristocratic Adventurers and other Fantasists. Players use melds of cards to retell the tales of the Baron & score points. Victory: The first player to score 100 points wins.”

The deck contains seven types of cards, inspired by elements of the Munchausen stories: Dramatic Mood Swings, Extraordinary Companion, Romantic Interlude, Brush with Death, Exotic Location, Preposterous Escape, and Envious Enemy. In addition, there are two Jokers and two Fools.

Unusual twists to the game include the “Side Bets and Wagers” phase in which players may wager over the truth of “any claim whatsoever”, with the loser required to give a card (or other agreed upon stake) to the winner of the wager. In addition, there is the “Ungentlemanly Conduct Rule”, which allows you to steal a random card from an opponent’s hand once per game.

name: Nijntje voert de dieren
description:
In Nijntje voert de Dieren, you will learn what the animals want to eat. Every player will receive the same number of food chips and tries to be the first to have fed all his/her chips to the animals.

On your turn you spin the wheel with animals and if Nijntje (Miffy) points at an animal which you can feed with one of your chips, you can feed the animal. First one to have fed all his/her chips, wins.

name: Pomerium
description:
"A solo game of warfare and intrigue in the Roman Empire."

"The time frame is somewhere between 50 and 150 AD. An emperor of long standing has just died. You happen to know with certainty that you are his intended successor, but he died before announcing this to the Senate. Your job: defeat the other powerful contenders to the throne and claim your rightful place as Imperator!"

The designer notes: "The scope of the player's choices in the game is somewhat limited, possibly making this more of a simulation than a strategy game. However, it was my intent to construct something that can be played as a simple pastime rather than with a great deal of advanced forethought."

name: Fluss der Drachen
description:
By a deep ravine winds the river of the dragons. There's something special about this game, however - the river bed is filled before playing with approx. 1 liter of water! The sailing boat of the king rides on the water, loaded with jewels. The players slip into the role of wild river dragons who want to steal the jewels. The only player who can do that, however, is one who has his breath well under control. Players move the ship by blowing through a straw to propel it along the river... but other players can end the trip by rolling the dice. In order to win, one needs a good portion of skill and dice luck beside sufficient breath. A damp-merry pleasure, which is also good for adults owing to a play variant for super dragons.

-- paraphrased from Spiel des Jahres entry

http://spieldesjahres.kiratec.eu/cms/front_content.php?idcat...;id=527
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Dice, Fantasy, Nautical

name: Zorogolf
description:
Zorogolf is a golf simulator game played with dice and cards. A course of nine holes is waiting you. Lakes, the forest, bunkers,... try to beat the course and your opponents by choosing the correct club.

Choose an iron or a wood and shoot for the hole in one!

name: Games of Life
description:
From the rules: "Games of Life, 'Count the Cost' Etc. and C.C. Lessons. Good as a book for youth and adults. Youth - learn while you play. Adults - play while you live."

A custom deck of cards with rules for six different games:

1. Count the Cost - "Trick taking game. For 2 or more. Best for 4." "One who accumulates most property wins."

2. Game of Life No. 1 - Trick taking game. "Win most LIFE cards, Nos. 5 to 9."

3. Game of Life No. 2 - "Object is to collect sets of four cards each containing the words GAME, LIFE, WORK, PLAY, LOVE, REST, READ."

4. Game of Life No. 3 - "Use only NAME cards like the old game of Authors."

5. C.C. Football Game - A trick taking game. "For 2 or 4 players." A football field marked on a sheet of paper - a heavy line is marked in the center and ten lines on each side of the field. Card play is used to move a button from the center toward the goal lines. Each goal scores 10 points, after which the button is returned to the center line.

6. Charity or Getting Rid of the Blues - "Teaching that 'it is better to give than receive.' Like the very old game of Give-away."

name: Domino Squares
description:
Each domino square is a double domino. Instead of two parts, each has four. Play can play all of the standard domino games like Block, Draw and Mexican Train, or play the exclusive new "Domino Squares" game. Includes 45 Domino Square dominoes (equivalent to 90 regular dominoes), scorepad and rules.

From the publisher's website:

Winning Moves Games takes dominoes to a new dimension with Domino Squares. They’re twice the size of regular dominoes for double the fun–and players score on every turn (score sheets provided). Enjoy playing Domino Squares!

The pieces found in Domino Squares have four advantages over common dominoes:

1. Each is a "double domino" – a large square comprised of four smaller squares (like two rectangular dominoes joined together).

2. Some pieces cause actions to occur. These are called "Command" pieces and contain words or phrases like "Skip" and "Draw 1".

3. Pieces can be played with more variety. You may play a piece that matches any of the three open-sides of either "end" piece on the layout.

4. Scoring occurs on every turn. After it is played, points are awarded for the "scoring side" of a piece (its two unmatched squares.)
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Suburban Wars
description: Suburban Wars is a stand-alone card game of Nutty Neighborhood Nonsense in which the objective is to the score the most Bliss points, which you do by playing Object cards from your hand to your Lot or Action cards from your hand on your opponents' Lots. In addition to the Object and Action cards from the Neighbor deck there's an Event deck with People and Occasion cards that keep the game spiced up. People wander the neighborhood causing trouble for you and your neighbors and everyone has to stop for the next holiday and partake in the festivities, usually in the form of some tweak to your hands or the rules. There are 120 cards and the game can be played by 2-6 players of ages 8+ in about 30 minutes.

name: Fix the Fence
description:
In this fun, challenging memory game, players flip cards to reveal hidden fencing supplies. Locate matching fence posts or wire cards to mend a section of downed fence. Find a match and place it on your mat. But, watch out for broken fence cards! Be the first to fill your mat and Fix the Fence!

Contents:
24 Cards
2 Playing Mats
1 Rulebook

http://www.farmgame.com/fixFence.asp

name: Hopton vs. Waller: Three Battles of the English Civil War 1643-1644
description:
Sixth entry in the English Civil War series, features three different battles, Lansdown, Roundway Down and Cheriton, each with a separate map (in a A4 sheet) and a total of around 150 counters.
These are fast and furious battles, with very few counters and a mechanic (chit drawing for the activation of leaders) that is very good both for solitaire than competitive play.

Available as direct download (then print & play) through Wargamedownloads.com

The English Civil War battle of Lansdowne (or Lansdown) was fought on July 5, 1643, near Bath. Although the Royalists under Lord Hopton forced the Parliamentarians under Sir William Waller to retreat from their hilltop position, they suffered so many casualties themselves and were left so disordered and short of ammunition that an injured Hopton was forced to retire.

The Battle of Roundway Down was fought on July 13, 1643, during the English Civil War. A Royalist cavalry force under Lord Wilmot won a crushing victory over the Parliamentarians under Sir William Waller who were besieging Devizes in central Wiltshire, which was defended by Lord Hopton.

The Battle of Cheriton was an important Parliamentarian victory in the English Civil War. It took place on March 29, 1644 and resulted in the defeat of a Royalist army, which threw King Charles I onto the defensive for the remainder of the year.

Contains:
6 Page Rules
3 8.5x11" Maps
1 Player Aid
159 Counters
categories: Civil War, Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Adventurer: Card Game – Chaos Expansion
description:
From publisher's website:

The Chaos Expansion is all about giving the players more control over their adventurers. With these new cards the player can now choose to encounter a danger, or not. Do they want attempt to open a possibly trapped chest? Failure might mean death, but success could bring a ton of treasure.

The Chaos Expansion also introduces a new way to win the game. Now instead of just being able to defeat the vampire lord to win the game, players can collect Chests of Power. The first player to collect three wins.

- Choose what your hero encounters and whether the risk is worth the reward!
- Change the way you win the game
- Hire henchmen to create strategic options
- Explore new magical obstacles, traps, and random event cards
- Discover powerful treasures
- Chaos also includes 1 new hero -- Made by Robert Doyel!"
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Medieval

name: Familien-Bande
description:
Who of you am I?
Who of us would like to be a Rock-Star?
Who uses the telephone for the longest time?

By mixing up your family you change into another role. Guess who I am and find out what I do.

A "family-game" where you learn more about others....

name: WWII Plastic Skirmish
description:
Tactical miniatures rules designed for use with plastic army men figures. The game may also be played with 15-25mm figures, or free print-and-play paper miniatures that are provided with the rules.

Additional equipment required for play includes a standard card deck for each player, a twelve-sided die, a yardstick, terrain features, and accessories (vehicles, cannons, pillboxes, etc.).

Ten historical scenarios are included, covering actions from 1939 (Poland) to 1944 (D-Day). Specific engagements covered include a British SAS jeep assault on an airfield in North Africa, a German assault on the Red October factory in Stalingrad, and the British glider assault on the Orne River bridge (Pegasus Bridge). The scenarios require a play area ranging from 3x5 to 5x9 feet.

“Designer's Notes: This game is not so silly as it looks and sound tactics are rewarded. It lends itself surprisingly well to re-creations of small scale (or reduced scale) historical battles.”

name: I'll See You at Ticonderoga
description:
A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played using 1/72 scale miniature figures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

“Ticonderoga was a French fort near Lake Champlain in Upper New York state. It acted as a guard to the approach to Quebec. In 1758, the British-American army under the command of Gen. Abercrombie and Lord Howe were to take the fort while Gen. Amherst was to capture the Fortress of Louisbourg. Only Amherst was successful.”

“Ticonderoga was a star shaped fort but the main fighting took places in a series of outer works away from the fort. The area was bordered by two rivers and the area was also swampy. An amazing fact of this battle was that it was completely fought by infantry without artillery support."

"The game table should be two meters by one meter. The French set up on the north side of the table. Green felt can be used to denote the flat open area, blue strips should simulate the rivers. Brown cloth, paper or battlefield accessories can be used to model the French trenches and abatis.”
categories: Age of Reason, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: UNO: Get Hooked
description: This edition has custom images of the University of Texas at Austin campus and Longhorns athlectics, each of the 112 cards celebrates the orange and white. Includes the exclusive Hook 'Em Card and Rule.

name: The International Cricket Series
description:
From the box lid:

"Captain your team to victory using all the tactical skill of a professional cricketer.

Unique card and dice combination provide all the excitement of a fast moving one day cricket match.

Easy to play - family fun."

This game is themed around the one-day cricket phenomenon that became popular in the late 70s, although the board game lasts for 10 overs instead of 50 like the real game.

Although the rules say that the game can be played by any number of players, in reality it seems to be designed for two people to oppose each other as the two team captains. Each captain has to make the same type of decisions that a cricket captain would normally make during a game, namely:


In what order to use his batsmen (four "top" batsmen, four "medium", and three "tail"); typically you would use your best batsmen first, as they have no individual characteristics such as skill against a certain type of bowling.



When to use his bowlers (two "strike" bowlers with one over each, two "medium" bowlers with two overs each, and two "spin" bowlers with two overs each). The rules suggest using your strike bowlers first to get the best batsmen out.



Where to place his fieldsmen; the bowler and wicket keeper have to be in their designated positions on the board, but the other nine can be placed in any one of 21 other named positions (mid-off, mid-on, extra cover, etc.). This seems to be where most of the decision-making takes place.


Once the batsmen, bowler, and fieldsmen are in place and ready, a bowler/batsman matchup table is consulted to determine which of three coloured dice is rolled:


the black die (1,1,2,3,3,4), which favours neither batsman nor bowler
the blue die (1,2,3,4,4,6), which favours the batsman
the red die (1,1,1,2,2,4), which favours the bowler


The indicated die is rolled. On a six, the batsman simply scores six runs (the maximum). On a 1 to 4, a card is drawn from the relevant deck, there being four named "Card One" to "Card Four"). Each card has three possible outcomes, one for each type of bowler. The relevant outcome is evaluated based on the positions of the fieldsmen. For example, one of the "Card Three" cards says this for the "strike" bowler:

"Driven in the air for some distance but a bad bounce beats mid-off who stumbles after it for 2 runs. No mid-off, 3 runs. No long-off, 4 runs."

Some cards call for the red die to be rolled, in which case the batsman must roll a 1 NOT to be given out (50% chance).

The innings is over once ten batsmen are out or ten overs have been completed. Each team has one innings, after which the team with the higher score wins the game.

name: Charts
description:
The first game release of Michael Schacht based on his 1995 finalist of the "Hippodice Autorenwettbewerb".

The game is about producing bands and releasing records. Depending on the positions in the charts the players get more or less fame and money.

name: Mangola
description:
A mangala game.

From Wikimanqala:

http://www.wikimanqala.org/wiki/Mangola_%28traditional%29

"Mangola has become in recent decades the most popular Mancala game played in the Democratic Republic of Congo. It is known from the Virunga mountains to the Sudanese border, and from Bangui (Central African Republic) to Arui near Uganda. Mangola is a new game which was developed after 1911 according to the ethnologue Philip Townshend and is now gradually replacing older games such as sombi and single lap mancala games. The game was spread by the Belgian colonial administration and military along rivers and roads and is the only mancala game played in the central basin (one of the few African regions where mancala games were still unknown in the 19th century).
There are many local variants, probably more than 30, which have slightly different opening rules (some with simultaneous opening moves) and employ different board sizes.
The game is played by adults on beautiful wooden boards with holes carved in the surface. Children, on the other hand, dig the board in the ground or draw it with chalk on concrete.
It is played by both sexes, but more often by women.
The following rules were reported from the capital Kinshasa by Suzanne Comhaire-Sylvain in 1952.

Rules:

Mangola is a two players game.
It is played on a board made of four rows of eight holes.
At the beginning each hole has two seeds.

Each player controls the two rows closer on his side, and only moves on these two rows. We will call the row closest to him outer row and the other one inner row
Players take turns to move.
The first move of each player is a special one: they redistribute the seeds by taking the contents of one hole and putting it into the next, and so one, until your side of the board is checkered with holes containing 4 seeds and empty holes.

The second move of each player must begin from the left- or right-most hole of your outer or inner row.
At your turn you take all the seeds from a hole on your side that contains at least two seeds and put them, one by one, in the following holes, in an anticlockwise sense. Singletons cannot be moved.
If the last seed is dropped in an empty hole, you move it to the next hole and your turn ends.
If the last seed falls in a non-empty hole, you take its contents including the last distributed seed and keep on sowing.
If the last seed falls in a non-empty hole of the inner row, and the two opposite holes of the opponent contain seeds, you take the contents of your hole, including the seed just dropped, and the contents of both opponent's holes, and begin the next lap from the hole following the last empty hole (the same from which you began the last lap that effected the capture).
When one player cannot move (his side of the board is empty or contains only singletons), he has lost the game."

name: Race for the Presidency
description: This hefty game gives players the opportunity to battle to become President of the United States. The board is divided into an inner board, in which electoral votes are collected via luck; and an outer board in which votes are collected via strategic positioning. Players can trade votes, funds, and favors throughout the game as they try to set themselves up to successfully debate issues to collect more votes.

name: Diamonds
description:
Diamonds is a positional game with the object of forming groups of four pieces of any size. All men move like the Queen in Chess with the additional force of over-leaping friendly and hostile pieces. Whoever forms a diamond may
decimate opponent’s forces. The player loses when he/she has only three men left.

name: Le Tour de Piste
description: French indoor cycling game that won a price at the Concours Lépine International in Paris. The board is quite large, measuring 81x51 cm. and the box contains 6 teams with 4 wooden cyclists and a dernyrider (generic for a small pacing motorcycle and rider used in cycle races). There also is a pawn to count the game turns and there are 8 cards to determine the starting order.

name: Die Maus: Mit Köpfchen
description:
Die Maus - Mit Köpfchen is a fast childrens word guessing game.

One player turns over one of 33 cards showing terms like 'A meal with...', 'A toy with...', 'A pet with...'. Then he rolls 6 dice. 5 dice (each with a different color) show letters. The sixth die is a colored die that indicates which of the letter dice is to be used. If it shows the white color any player can choose any rolled letter die he wants. Now all players simultaneously try to guess a word corresponding to the term on the card that starts with the rolled letter. The first players that finds a word gets the card as prize.

The game stops when all cards are won by the players. The player with the most cards wins the game.

name: Scene It? To Go!: Movie
description:
All the fun of the original game is packed into these compact travel cases with on-screen trivia cards and dice! Magnetic game tokens make it possible to play Scene It? anytime, anywhere.

The compact travel case features real movie clips, trivia questions and on-screen challenges from Hollywood's hottest films, including Titanic, There's Something About Mary, Fargo and more!
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: A Knight's Tale
description:
"What say you, Brave Knight?". A piecepack port of Joe Huber's Joust (in theme of Heath Ledger's "A Knight's Tale"). A Fast-paced, very simple, and fun game. There is a slight element of strategy (in the style of Rock, Paper, Scissors). The game is perfect to kick-start a gaming session.

Pre-programmed movement and attacks lead to interesting strategy!

Rules can be found on Piecepack Wiki

Game System

Piecepack Game System

name: Muumi Alias
description:
In Moomin Alias you explain words and pictures to your team mates without actually saying the word that is being explained, but by using synonyms and opposites, hints, etc. instead. The game can also be played by children who cannot read yet, as the pictures show the word to be explained. A fun and developing game for all Moomin lovers, big and small!

This is the Moomin version of Alias.
categories: Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip, Party Game, Racing, Word Game
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Team-Based Game

name: Marston Moor
description:
Marston Moor is the seventh entry in our introductory English Civil War tactical series. The rulebook integrates all the modifications and additional rules from the previous entries.
The Battle of Marston Moor was fought on 2 July 1644, during the First English Civil War of 1642–1646. The combined forces of the Scottish Covenanters under the Earl of Leven and the Parliamentarians under Lord Fairfax and the Earl of Manchester defeated the Royalists commanded by Prince Rupert of the Rhine and the Marquess of Newcastle.

Scale:
1 turn: 20 minutes
1 hex: 100 to 200 yards
1 strength point: 50 to 150 men

Contains:
5 Page rules
151 Counters and Markers
2 player aids
11x17" Color Map (2 8.x11" parts)
categories: Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Stonehenge: Bonusspiele #1
description:
This supplemental anthology of games for the Stonehenge game system was given to anyone who bought Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game at SPIEL 2007. It contains the rules for the following five games:


Der hohe Rat (political game) by Volker Hesselmann, for 2 or 4 players (2 vs. 2): The druids have to vote for or against a motion. Each player tries to convince his neighbor in the council. The aim is to get the majority within the council.
Erbaut Stonehenge (construction game) by Dustin D. Trammell, for 3 to 4 players: All players are building Stonehenge. Each player represents a single cult and tries to build the most magnificent elements and beat the other cults by reputation.
Rollende Steine (dexterity game) by Tyler Tinsley, for 1 to 5 players: Each player represents a celtic giant. The giants play their favorite game: Rolling stones through the triliths. 8 triliths compositions are proposed in the rules, others can be invented by the players. The player win or lose togehter.
Trilithen Knallen (carambolage racing game) by Nicolas and Volker Hesselmann for 2 to 5 players: During the annual carambolage race, a bunch of manic druids on their triliths try to ram the others by remembering the hidden cards. The last one on the course wins the race.
Opferroulette (luck game) by Jason Bulmahn for 2 to 5 players: The players are gods and try to promote their favorite to become the high priest. To do so, they need to avoid the oblation of their priest while destroying the other ones during the ancestral stone-sphere game.


A PDF of Bonusspiele #1 can be acquired here (German).

name: Topps Attax
description:
A collectible card game that features Major League Baseball players.

The game plays much like Top Trumps. Each card has ratings in three categories: Fastball, Changeup, and Specialty. The pitching team selects one of his pitchers, then the hitting team places down one of his hitters, face-down. The pitching team then chooses one of the three categories, the hitter's card is revealed, and the higher total in the selected category wins. Each team gets to play 9 hitters, and the team with the most hitters' victories wins the game.

In 2011, additional rules were added to form the "Major League" rules, and the original ruleset was dubbed the "Home Run Derby"; cards were designed with additional information for the new rules. Under the Major League rules, the game takes place on a "baseball field" poster provided in the starter set. One pitcher pitches for an entire inning, but may not throw the same pitch twice in a row. Hits are no longer automatically home runs, but the batter moves a number of bases as indicated on his card. Players have offensive and defensive abilities that allow them to change the effects of hits, pitches, runs, and outs. Ball fields and mascots were added to the card set, and can affect the game.

From the starter box back:

Introducing Topps Attax, the new card game that puts you in charge of the action! Manage your team, call your pitches and battle against your friends. Or take the action online!
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Collectible Components, Number, Sports

name: Puss in the Corner
description:
Early children's game that is about as simple as they come. Spin and whatever color comes up gets a marker in their corner. First person with 4 markers in their corner wins.

A different game than the earlier 1895 game also published by Parker Brothers.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Daldøs
description:
An old scandinavian game, played in certain parts of Denmark and Norway. Two players take turns rolling the dice to try and free their pegs for movement, then try to capture the opponents pegs before they can ambush your starting pieces.

The board consists of three lines of holes for the pegs, the middle one being one hole longer than the two sides. The two side lines are filled with each player's pegs. The number of pegs vary according to local tradition, typically 16 in Denmark and 12 in Norway.
The game uses a pair of special four sided dice marked A, II, III and IV. You need to roll an A to free one of your pieces, the other rolls are used to move the pegs once freed. A peg may never overtake your other pegs, but must keep their place in the line.
Once freed the pieces move down the middle aisle and if they manage to avoid being captured they move into the opponent's starting line, capturing the unfree pegs.

The origins of the game are unknown but it is believed to be inspired by certain middle-eastern and north african games, brought back by either vikings or crusaders.

name: The Rooftops of Ludovia
description:
A game about thefts and crafty unfortunate events

The inhabitants of the tranquil and calm Rich District of the City of Ludovia haven’t got a clue that a group of thieves is keeping an eye on their houses.

Having recently arrived in the neighbourhood, the crooks founded a lair and in it formed a guild, to plan robberies and trickeries.
